Secs. 42-42-42-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DANCEHALLS AND DANCES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 42-81. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this Section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Public dance means any dance to which admission can be had by payment directly or indirectly of a fee, or any dance to which the public generally may gain admission with or without the payment of a fee. 
    Public dancehall means any room, place or space in which a public dance shall be held. 
(Code 1975, § 11-707) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 42-82. - Closing time. 
    All public dances shall be discontinued and all public dancehalls shall be closed between 2:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m. 
(Code 1975, § 11-705) 
Secs. 42-83-42-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 42-101. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, either as principal, agent or employee, to conduct, pursue, carry on, or operate any public dance in any hall or public place or to permit dancing in such place within the limits of the City, without first paying the business license fee in the sum established by ordinance or a daily fee established by ordinance and procuring a license therefor from the City Clerk. 
(Code 1975, § 11-701; Ord. No. G-1203, § 1, 7-22-2014) 
Sec. 42-102. - Application. 
    In no event shall any such license be issued unless the applicant shall file an application in writing to the City Clerk at least 15 days prior to the consideration of the application by the Board of Commissioners. The application shall state the location at which the proposed dances are to be held, the type of building in which any dance is to be operated, and that the building has been approved in writing by the chief of the Fire Department as being safe insofar as fire hazards are concerned and by the Building Official as being in compliance with the City's building, electrical, plumbing and mechanical codes. 
(Code 1975, § 11-701) 
Sec. 42-103. - Issuance standards. 
    The Board of Commissioners shall not issue any such license until the application therefor has been reviewed by the Chief of Police and thereafter the application being approved by the Board of Commissioners upon finding that: 
(1)  The granting of the license will not be detrimental to the neighborhood in which it is proposed to be located; and 
(2)  Granting the license is for the best interests of the City and the inhabitants thereof. 
In making these findings one of the factors, but not the sole factor, to be considered shall be whether the applicant, or anyone acting on the applicant's behalf including, but not limited to, the applicant's spouse, agent, servant, employee, corporation, partner or trustee, within the previous 24 months has violated any provision of this article or any other ordinance or laws or regulations relating to such places, including those relating to the possession, consumption, dispensing or furnishing of alcoholic and/or cereal malt beverages. 
(Code 1975, § 11-701) 
Sec. 42-104. - Posting. 
    No license for a public dancehall shall be issued to any person until it shall be found that the place for which it is issued complies with and conforms to all laws, ordinances, health and fire regulations applicable thereto including, but not limited to, the City's building, electrical, plumbing and mechanical codes, and is properly ventilated and supplied with separate and sufficient toilet conveniences for each sex, and is a safe and proper place for public dances. Every person to whom a dancehall license is issued shall post the license in a conspicuous place in the dancehall covered by such license. 
(Code 1975, § 11-702) 
Sec. 42-105. - Fee. 
    The license for a dancehall, if the building is also the location of duly licensed drinking establishment, shall extend for the period covered by the license issued by the state authorizing a drinking establishment. If the building is not licensed as a drinking establishment, the dancehall license shall be issued on a calendar year basis. No license fee for a dancehall shall be refunded for any reason. 
(Code 1975, § 11-706; Ord. No. G-1203, § 2, 7-22-2014) 
Sec. 42-106. - Revocation for cause. 
    The Governing Body may, upon five days' notice to the person holding such license, revoke any such license for: 
(1)  Violating within the previous 24 months any provision of this article or any other ordinance or laws or regulations relating to such places, including those relating to the possession, consumption, dispensing or furnishing of alcoholic and/or cereal malt beverages; or 
(2)  Revocation of the license is for the best interests of the City and the inhabitants thereof. 
Within 20 days after the order of the Governing Body revoking the dancehall license, the licensee may appeal to the county District Court, in the manner as provided by law for appeals from decisions made by City governing bodies. In case of revocation of the license of any licensee, no new license shall be issued to any such person, or anyone acting upon the licensee's behalf including, but not limited to, the applicant's spouse, agent, servant, employee, corporation, partner or trustee for a period of one year from date of revocation. The Governing Body shall suspend any license of any licensee upon whom notice of revocation has been ordered, which suspension shall become effective immediately and shall remain in full force and effect until the appeal has been determined. 
(Code 1975, § 11-703) 
Secs. 42-107-42-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MISCELLANEOUS SALES 

Sec. 42-141. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this Section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Miscellaneous sale means any garage, basement, yard, rummage, or other similar sale of three or more miscellaneous items that were originally purchased by the miscellaneous sales applicant for his ultimate use. 
(Code 1975, § 11-801) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 42-142. - License required. 
    No person shall conduct or carry on in the City a miscellaneous sale without having first paid the license fee as provided in Section 42-41 and obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1975, § 11-802) 
Sec. 42-143. - Regulations. 
    All miscellaneous sales shall conform to the following regulations: 
(1)  Application. Application for the miscellaneous sale shall be submitted to the license collector, and such application shall contain a statement that all items were purchased for use by the applicant. 
(2)  Sale limits. No applicant or persons residing with the applicant shall have more than two sales in a 12-month period, and such sale shall be limited to three consecutive days. However, schools, churches, and nonprofit organizations may carry on miscellaneous sales for the benefit of the organization when such sale is conducted on school, church, or commercial property, without obtaining a permit. 
(3)  Signs. Signs advertising the sale shall not exceed two signs of two square feet each, and shall be displayed only on the licensed property the days of such sale. 
(Code 1975, § 11-803) 
Secs. 42-144-42-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SOLICITORS AND PEDDLERS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 42-171. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this Section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Charitable means and includes the terms "patriotic," "philanthropic," "social service," "welfare," "benevolent," "educational," "civic," or "fraternal," either actual or purported. 
    Licensed solicitor or peddler means any person who has obtained a valid permit and license as provided in this article, which permit and license is in the possession of the solicitor or peddler on his person while engaged in soliciting or peddling. 
    Peddler means any person, whether a resident of the City or not, traveling by foot, wagon, automotive vehicle or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, merchant to merchant, or from street to street, carrying, conveying or transporting goods, wares, merchandise, meat, fish, vegetables, fruits, truck garden or farm products or other foods stuffs, offering and exposing them for sale, or making sales and delivering articles to purchasers, or who, without traveling from place to place, sells or offers the same for sale from a wagon, automotive vehicle, railroad car, or other vehicle or conveyance; unless otherwise licensed under the provisions of any other ordinances of the City. 
    Person means the singular and the plural and any person, firm, corporation, association, club, partnership, society, or any other organization, and the agents, servants or representatives thereof, including any religious or charitable organizations. 
    Premises means any building or property used for residential, commercial, educational, or industrial activity. 
    Solicitor means any person, whether a resident of the City or not, traveling either by foot, wagon, automobile, motor truck, or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, house to house, merchant to merchant, or from street to street, or making contact by telephone, taking or attempting to take orders for sale of goods, wares, and merchandise, foodstuffs, or personal property of any nature whatsoever, for future delivery, or for service whether or not such individual has, carries, or exposes for sale a sample of the subject of such sale, or whether such person is collecting advance payment on such sales or not. 
(Code 1975, § 11-201) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 42-172. - Duty of police to enforce article provisions. 
    It shall be the duty of any police officer of the City to require any person seen soliciting or peddling and who is not known by such officer to be duly licensed, to produce both the permit and the license and to enforce the provisions of this article against any person found to be violating the same. 
(Code 1975, § 11-210) 
Sec. 42-173. - Operation in congested areas. 
    It shall be unlawful to use a stationary location in or upon any public street, or operate in any congested area where operations might impede or inconvenience the public. For the purpose of this Section, the judgement of a police officer, exercised in good faith, shall be deemed conclusive as to whether the area is congested or the public impeded or inconvenienced. 
(Code 1975, § 11-208(a)) 
Sec. 42-174. - Operation on private property. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate on private property without having first secured the permission of the owner or occupant of such property. 
(Code 1975, § 11-208(b)) 
Sec. 42-175. - Sales from vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale goods, wares, or merchandise from vehicles on any of the public streets of the City. The prohibition contained in this Section shall not include the peddling from door to door, or from vehicles, of fresh food products of a farm or garden, nor bona fide deliveries of goods, wares, merchandise or foods made on a regular route to regular customers, or ice cream vending. 
(Code 1975, § 11-208(c)) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 78. 
Sec. 42-176. - Prohibited hours; signage. 
    It shall be unlawful to solicit or peddle from 9:00 p.m. to 9:00 a.m., or at anytime when a sign has been posted on a residence or building stating "No Solicitors or Peddlers," or words to that effect, except that a licensed solicitor or peddler may call upon the occupant of a residence at other times when he has received express prior permission from such occupant to do so. 
(Code 1975, § 11-208(d)) 
Sec. 42-177. - Nonprofit solicitation; permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful to solicit within the City for a contribution of funds for charitable, religious, educational, community, recreational, or similar nonprofit purpose by means of calling upon places of residence or by means of direct personal contact in public places or upon public property without obtaining a permit as provided by this article. Any peddling or soliciting by means of representation that all or a portion of the proceeds thereof are to be used for any person for any such purpose, is unlawful unless a permit is first obtained as provided by this article. 
(Code 1975, § 11-208(e)) 
Secs. 42-178-42-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 42-201. - Required. 
    Every person desiring to engage in soliciting, or peddling within this City is required to make written application for license as provided in this article. Such license shall be carried on the person of the solicitor or peddler. 
(Code 1975, § 11-202) 
Sec. 42-202. - Application. 
    Application for a license shall be made in duplicate upon a form provided by the City. The applicant shall truthfully state in full the information requested on the application: 
(1)  The name and address of the present place of personal residence and the length of residence at such address; and, in addition thereto, the business address if different from the personal residence. 
(2)  The address of the place of personal and business residence during the past three years if other than the present address. 
(3)  The age of the applicant. 
(4)  A physical description of the applicant. 
(5)  The name and address of the person by whom the applicant is employed or represents, and the length of time of such employment or representation. 
(6)  The name and address of the person for whom the applicant has worked or represented during the past three years. 
(7)  A description sufficient to identify the property or service which the applicant intends to peddle or take orders for. 
(8)  The period of time for which the license is requested. 
(9)  The date, or approximate date, of the latest previous application for a license under this article, if any. 
(10)  A statement to the effect that if a license is granted, it will not be used or represented in any way as an endorsement by the City, or by any department or officer thereof. 
(11)  A statement whether or not a license issued to the applicant under this article has ever been revoked. 
(12)  A statement whether or not the applicant has ever been convicted of a felony under the laws of the State of Kansas, any other state or the laws of the United States of America; and, if so, a detailed description of the offense, the sentencing court, the sentence imposed, and the terms and provisions thereof. 
(13)  An applicant for a solicitor's or peddler's license shall supply the City with two photographs of the applicant taken within at least 60 days prior to the date of the filing of the application, which photographs shall be at least two inches by two inches, showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner. 
All statements made by the applicant upon the application or in connection therewith shall be under oath. 
(Code 1975, § 11-203) 
Sec. 42-203. - Investigation and issuance. 
(a)  Upon receipt of such application, the original shall be referred to the Chief of Police who shall cause such investigation of the applicant's business or moral character to be made as deemed necessary for the protection of the public health, morals, safety and welfare of the citizens of the City. 
(b)  If, as a result of such investigation, the Chief of Police is of the opinion that the application should be denied for the protection of the health, morals, safety, or welfare of the citizens, the Chief of Police shall state his reasons for the same, and return the application to the Department of Finance, who shall notify the applicant that his application is denied and that no permit and license will be issued. 
(c)  If, as a result of such investigation, the Chief of Police determines the applicant should be issued a license and permit, he shall endorse on the application his approval, execute a permit in the name of the applicant, and return such permit, along with the application to the Department of Finance, who shall, upon payment of the prescribed license fee, and filing the required bond, deliver to the applicant the permit and issue a license. The license shall contain the signature of an authorized employee from the Department of Finance, and shall show the name, address and photograph of the such licensee, the class of license issued and the kind of goods to be sold thereunder, the amount of fee paid, the date of issuance and the length of time the same shall be operative, as well as the license number and other identifying description of any vehicle or conveyance used in such peddling or soliciting. The Department of Finance shall keep a permanent record of all licenses issued. 
(Code 1975, § 11-204; Ord. No. G-1177, § 7, 2-12-2013) 
Sec. 42-204. - Fees. 
    Before a license is issued, the fee as prescribed in article II of this chapter shall be paid to the City. Any period of time of more than 30 calendar days and not more than one calendar year shall be treated as one year. 
(Code 1975, § 11-205) 
Sec. 42-205. - Bond. 
(a)  Generally. Every solicitor or peddler, prior to receiving the permit and license, shall file with the City Clerk a surety bond, running to the City in the amount of $1,000.00, with a surety acceptable to and approved by the City Attorney, conditioned that the applicant shall comply fully with all the provisions of the ordinances of the City, and the state statutes regulating and concerning the business of peddlers and solicitors and guaranteeing to any citizen of the City, that all money paid as a down payment will be accounted for and applied according to the representations of the peddler and solicitor, and further guaranteeing to any citizen of the City, doing business with any peddler or solicitor, that the property or services purchased will be delivered or performed according to the representations of such peddler or solicitor. Such bond shall be for the period of time covered by the license. 
(b)  Exception. Religious and charitable organizations having permanent residence within the corporate limits of the City are excepted. Action on such a bond may be brought in the name of the City to the use or benefit of the aggrieved person. 
(Code 1975, § 11-207) 
Sec. 42-206. - Expiration. 
    The license shall remain in force and effect for the period specified therein, and shall be renewed upon the expiration of this period upon filing a new application as provided in this article. 
(Code 1975, § 11-206) 
Sec. 42-207. - Exhibition upon request. 
    No peddler or solicitor, or any person acting in behalf of either, shall refuse to exhibit the license issued to him under the provisions of this division at the request of any person. 
(Code 1975, § 11-208(f)) 
Sec. 42-208. - Revocation. 
    Any license issued under this article shall be revoked by the Chief of Police if the holder of the license is convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this article, or has made a false material statement in the application for the issuance of a license under the terms of this article. Immediately upon such revocation, written notice thereof shall be given to the City Clerk to the holder of the license in person or by certified United States mail, return receipt requested, addressed to the residence address set forth in the application. 
(Code 1975, § 11-209) 
Secs. 42-209-42-240. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - TAXICABS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 78. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 42-241. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this Section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Taxicab means any and all motor vehicles carrying passengers for hire, for which public patronage is solicited; provided, however, that railway cars and motor buses operating under a franchise from the City or operating under authority and jurisdiction of the state corporation commission shall not be deemed taxicabs within the meaning hereof. 
(Code 1975, § 11-601) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 42-242. - Register of taxicabs. 
    The City Clerk shall keep a register showing the name and address of each person owning a taxicab licensed under this article, with the license number, description and make of such taxicab. Such register shall be a public record and open to inspection by the public at all times. 
(Code 1975, § 11-610) 
Sec. 42-243. - Appeals. 
    If any owner or operator of a taxicab feels aggrieved by the suspension or revocation of his license pursuant to Section 42-296 and this Section, he may appeal the determination to the Governing Body, and the Governing Body shall fix a date, place, and time for the hearing on the appeal. At the hearing, evidence may be produced by the owner or operator to show why the suspension or revocation should not be imposed; after which, the Governing Body shall notify the operator or owner of its decision, and such decision shall be final. 
(Code 1975, § 11-629A) 
Sec. 42-244. - Inspection; maintenance. 
(a)  When an application for a taxicab license or the transfer of a license from one vehicle to another is filed with the City Clerk, he shall refer the application to the Police Department, and it shall be the duty of the police officer designated as license inspector by the Chief of Police to examine such vehicle as to its cleanliness, physical and mechanical condition, lights and other equipment and to clarify to the Board of Commissioners his approval or rejection of such taxicab. In addition to the inspection required for the issuance of a license, it shall be the duty of the inspector for the Police Department to make an examination of each taxicab at least once each six months from the date of the original inspection, or oftener if necessary, as to its cleanliness, physical and mechanical condition. The inspecting officer is hereby empowered to suspend the license of such taxicab until the owner or operator of such taxicab shall have repaired the taxicab or restored such taxicab to such physical and mechanical condition as shall meet the approval of the license inspector. It shall be the duty of the license inspector upon the suspension of any such taxicab by him to report such suspension to the City Clerk. No owner, operator or driver of any taxicab so suspended by the license inspector shall allow or permit such taxicab to be used until the same has been reinspected and approved by the license inspector. 
(b)  Any taxicab failing to pass inspection because of unsanitary conditions shall be allowed to remain in service as a taxicab for 48 hours, at which time it will be reinspected. If the taxicab cleanliness has not been corrected, then such license shall be suspended. 
(c)  The owner or operator of a taxicab must submit the taxicab vehicle for inspection upon the request of the inspecting officer, except when such taxicab is in the process of picking up or carrying a passenger. 
(Code 1975, § 11-629) 
Sec. 42-245. - Numbering. 
    Every person operating one or more vehicles as a taxicab in the City under one license shall assign to each vehicle a number, commencing with Arabic number "1" and thereafter numbered consecutively. Such numbers shall be plainly painted and displayed upon the vehicles as required in Section 42-246. 
(Code 1975, § 11-624) 
Sec. 42-246. - Marking. 
    Every taxicab governed by the ordinances of the City shall have plainly painted upon the exterior of a side door on each side of the vehicle the name of the owner or operator holding the license under such operator, each of which shall be printed in letters and figures not less than two inches in height; and shall also have painted thereon the number assigned to the cab by the operator which shall be inscribed in numbers of not less than four inches in height. 
(Code 1975, § 11-625) 
Sec. 42-247. - Rates filed with the City Clerk. 
    The rates or fares to be charged to passengers conveyed by taxicabs within the corporate limits of the City shall be in accordance with the schedule of rates or fares filed with the City Clerk. Any amendments and changes in the rate schedule shall become effective seven days after a notice has been filed with the City Clerk. 
(Code 1975, § 11-627) 
Sec. 42-248. - Fare rate card. 
    Each taxicab shall be equipped with a placard displaying the rates or fares, and rate zone maps, to be charged to passengers, as filed with the City Clerk. The card, relating to the fares, and the zones, shall be so placed that it can be plainly seen by the passenger riding in such taxicab. The type used for the printing of rates or fares, and rate zone maps, shall be sufficient size so that it can be clearly read at a distance of three feet. 
(Code 1975, § 11-627A) 
Secs. 42-249-42-270. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BUSINESS LICENSE 

Sec. 42-271. - Required. 
    No person whether acting as owner, principal, agent, employee, lessee or licensee shall operate or permit to be operated on the streets of the City any taxicab without first having procured a license therefor as provided in this division. 
(Code 1975, § 11-602) 
Sec. 42-272. - Application. 
(a)  Any person whether acting as owner, principal, agent, employee, lessee or licensee, in order to secure an application for a license as provided for the operation of a taxicab, for the carriage of persons for hire within the City, shall file an application with the City Clerk for such license, which application shall be made by the owner of such taxicab on a blank form provided by the City Clerk and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The full name and address of the owners; 
(2)  The length of time the vehicle has been in use; 
(3)  The number of persons it is constructed or built to carry; 
(4)  A complete description of such vehicle, including the motive power, the model, motor and chassis number, state license number, the principal place of business, telephone number and office address of the owner; and if the owner is a corporation, the names of the officers and directors of such corporation, and if a partnership, the names of all the partners, together with such other information as the City Clerk or the Board of Commissioners may require. 
The application shall also specify the trade name under which the taxicab shall be operated, and the color or distinctive design of the body, if any. The application shall also be signed by the owner, if an individual, one of the partners if they are a partnership, and the managing officer of the corporation if it is a corporation. 
(b)  Upon the filing of an application with the City Clerk for a taxicab license by any person, the applicant shall fill out an application blank as provided in this Section, shall pay the appropriate license fee and shall deposit with the City Clerk the insurance policy required in Section 42-273. 
(Code 1975, §§ 11-603, 11-606) 
Sec. 42-273. - Insurance required. 
(a)  Before any license for a taxicab shall be issued, the owner shall file with the City Clerk an insurance binder confirming the issuance of a policy as directed in this Section. Such insurance shall cover each and every taxicab owned, operated, or leased by the applicant, providing liability coverage of not less than $100,000.00 for the injury or death of any one person, and $200,000.00 for the injury or death of any number of persons in any one accident, and also providing coverage of not less than $50,000.00 for property damages in any one accident. The insurance coverage must be effective whether the taxicab at the time of the accident is driven or operated by the owner, his agent, employee, lessee or licensee. The policy shall meet the requirements and conditions of the laws of the state, including personal injury protection benefits, and shall carry a uniform endorsement for actual notice to the City of any change made therein after its issuance. The binder policy and endorsements shall be approved by the City Attorney. Such insurance policy shall further provide that it cannot be cancelled until ten days' written notice of such cancellation has been filed with the City Clerk. 
(b)  Should the policy issued by an insurance company not legally authorized to do business in the state, then there shall be attached to such policy a written endorsement appointing and designating some person within the state as a resident agent of such company upon whom legal service of summons may be had. 
(c)  The cancellation or termination of insurance in force as provided in this Section shall automatically terminate any license issued for the taxicab covered by such insurance policy. 
(Code 1975, § 11-604) 
Sec. 42-274. - Issuance. 
    Within five days after the approval of such application for a license for a taxicab and the approval of the City Attorney of the insurance policy provided, the City Clerk shall issue a license for such taxicab. The license shall have endorsed thereon the City number of such license and the year for which it is issued. Such license shall be conspicuously displayed upon the windshield of such vehicle in the lower righthand corner and shall be kept there at all times. 
(Code 1975, § 11-608) 
Sec. 42-275. - Fee. 
    Before the issuance of the license provided for in Section 42-274, the applicant for such license shall pay to the Department of Finance a license fee as specified in Section 42-41. 
(Code 1975, § 11-609; Ord. No. G-1177, § 8, 2-12-2013) 
Secs. 42-276-42-290. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DRIVER'S LICENSE 

Sec. 42-291. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to act as a driver of a taxicab without having first secured a license as a driver to be issued by the City Clerk. 
(Code 1975, § 11-611) 
Sec. 42-292. - Application; contents; examination fee. 
    Such license shall be applied for in writing on such forms as the City Clerk may prescribe, and such application shall include: 
(1)  Whether or not the applicant has a valid state driver's license and whether his driver's license has ever been revoked or suspended, and, if so, the date of such revocation or suspensions; 
(2)  Whether or not the applicant has a valid driver's license issued by a state other than the State of Kansas and whether his driver's license has ever been revoked or suspended and, if so, the date of such revocation or suspension; 
(3)  The number of times and places arrested and/or convicted for traffic violations; and 
(4)  The name of the person by whom the applicant is employed. 
All applications for a taxicab driver's license shall be accompanied by the payment of an examination fee established by ordinance which shall not be subject to refund. 
(Code 1975, § 11-611) 
Sec. 42-293. - Applicant requirements. 
    Every applicant must be at least 18 years of age, and must have a valid driver's license issued by the states of Kansas, Missouri or Oklahoma. 
(Code 1975, § 11-613) 
Sec. 42-294. - Expiration and renewal. 
    All taxicab driver's licenses shall expire on December 31 of each year. Upon the expiration of such license, the driver shall be required to obtain a new license upon the payment of such fee established by ordinance, which fee shall not be subject to refund; provided, however, that in case the driver shall apply for a new license on or before December 20 of each year, no new application shall be required. Each application for a renewal license shall be accompanied by a fee established by ordinance, which fee shall be paid to the City treasurer. 
(Code 1975, § 11-614) 
Sec. 42-295. - Identification card. 
(a)  Issuance. At the time the driver's license is issued, the driver's license identification card shall also be issued. Such card shall be of a form prescribed by the City Clerk and shall contain the pictures of the driver affixed in such a manner that another picture cannot be substituted therefor without detection. The driver's license number, card number, and the expiration date of such license shall also be shown thereon. 
(b)  Display. The taxicab driver's license identification card shall be conspicuously displayed in such a manner that the entire card is visible from the rear seat of the automobile which the driver is operating, and the only license identification card displayed shall be the one belonging to the driver who is on duty at that time. Such card shall be enclosed in a frame, with glass or other transparent front, so that the card shall be clearly discernible to and can be read by the passenger in the rear seat. No driver shall operate a taxicab unless he shall have his identification card in good condition, and it shall be unlawful to have a torn or illegible card. 
(c)  Loss. If an identification card is lost, the owner may file with the City Clerk a sworn statement of the facts concerning such loss, and, if satisfied that the facts justify the issuance of a replacement card, the City Clerk shall on the payment to the City treasurer of a fee established by ordinance, issue a duplicate card. Such duplicate card shall be plainly marked "duplicate," and the number of the original card shall be furnished to the Police Department, as well as the number of the duplicate card. 
(Code 1975, §§ 11-615-11-617) 
Sec. 42-296. - Revocation. 
    A taxicab driver's license shall be suspended for up to 90 days or revoked by the Chief of Police for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  For operating a taxicab while under the influence of alcohol or drugs; 
(2)  For leaving the scene of an accident; 
(3)  For failure to make full report of an accident to the Police Department; 
(4)  For permitting any other person to use his license or identification card; 
(5)  Upon conviction of one or more major traffic violations during any one license year. A major traffic violation is hereby defined to be: 
a.  Speeding; 
b.  Reckless driving; 
c.  Nonobservance of lights or signs; 
d.  Driving while drunk; 
e.  Making a left or U-turn where not permitted; and 
f.  Driving on the wrong side of the street. 
(6)  Not having a valid driver's license or having such license revoked or suspended. 
(Code 1975, § 11-618) 
Secs. 42-297-42-304. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SEXUALLY ORIENTED BUSINESSES 

Sec. 42-305. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article the following definitions shall apply. 
(1)  Religious institution. A building which is used primarily for religious worship and related religious activities. 
    The following words, terms and phrases shall be considered as, or pertaining to "adult entertainment uses" or "sexually oriented uses": 
(2)  Adult amusement/adult entertainment. Amusement or entertainment which is distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on acts or material depicting, describing or relating to "sexual conduct/sexual activity" or "specified anatomical areas", as defined herein. 
(3)  Adult bookstore. An establishment devoting 50 percent or more of its interior display area for the sale, rental or any other form of payment to one or more of the following: (a) books, magazines, other printed matter, photographs, film, motion pictures, video cassettes, compact discs, slides or other visual representations which are characterized by their emphasis on depicting, describing or relating to "sexual conduct/sexual activity" or "specified anatomical areas"; and/or (b) instruments, devices or paraphernalia that is marketed or designed for use primarily for stimulation of human genitalia; and/or (c) is an establishment that holds itself out to the public as a purveyor of such materials based upon its signage, advertising, displays, actual sales, presence of video preview or coin-operated booths, the exclusion of minors from the establishment's premises, or any other factors showing that the establishment's primary purpose is to purvey such material. 
(4)  Adult cabaret. A public or private nightclub, bar, restaurant or similar establishment which features: a) live performances which are distinguished or characterized by exposure of "specified anatomical areas"; or, b) entertainers, employees or patrons which display "specified anatomical areas"; or, c) entertainers, employees or patrons who by reason of their appearance or conduct perform in a manner which is designed primarily to appeal to the sexual interest of the patron; or, d) entertainers, employees or patrons who engage in explicit simulation of "sexual activities"; or, e) films, motion pictures, video cassettes, slides or other photographic reproductions which are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on depicting or describing "sexual conduct" or "specified anatomical areas". 
(5)  Adult establishment. Any business establishment which offers services to a member of the public and in which adult entertainment takes place. 
(6)  Adult hotel/motel. A hotel or motel which leases its rooms on less than a daily basis. 
(7)  Adult mini motion picture theater. An enclosed building with a capacity of less than 50 persons used for presenting material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on depicting or describing "sexual conduct" or "specified anatomical areas". 
(8)  Adult motion picture arcade. Any place at which slug-operated or electronically, electrically or mechanically controlled, still or motion picture machines, projectors of other image producing devices are maintained to show images to five or fewer persons per machine at any one time, and where the images so displayed are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on depicting or describing "sexual conduct" or "specified anatomical areas". 
(9)  Adult motion picture theater. An enclosed building with a capacity of 50 or more persons used for regularly presenting material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on depicting or describing "sexual conduct" or "specified anatomical areas". This definition does not apply to those theaters that follow the Motion Picture Association of America (MPAA) rating system of G, PG, PG-13, R, and NC-17. 
(10)  Adult theater. A theater, concert hall auditorium or similar establishment which, for any form of consideration, regularly features live performances which are characterized by the exposure of "specified anatomical areas" or by "sexual activities". 
(11)  Cluster effect. When commercial establishments offering a particular good or service group themselves together, thus inducing other businesses offering the same or similar good or service to locate there as well. 
(12)  Employee. Any person retained to perform work or is subject to dismissal or termination from work at an adult use establishment. 
(13)  Massage parlor. Any place where for any form of consideration or gratuity, a massage, alcohol rub, administration of fomentations, electric or magnetic treatments, or any other treatment or manipulation of the human body occurs as part of or in connection with "sexual conduct/sexual activity" or where any person providing such treatment, manipulation or services related thereto exposes "specified anatomical areas". 
No part of this definition will be deemed to deprive any member of the healing arts to perform manipulation of body parts as part of the profession or professional training of said persons by licensed practitioners. Licensed practitioners shall include but not be limited to: nurses, physicians, surgeons, chiropractors, chiropodists, podiatrists, osteopaths, physical therapists, and massage therapists. 
(14)  Patron. A person who enters into a business or establishment, either by paying some form of monetary compensation or a membership fee, as a customer or private member, for the purpose of receiving services provided by a business or establishment located upon such premises. 
(15)  Sexual encounter center. Any building or structure which contains, or is used for commercial entertainment where the patron directly or indirectly is charged a fee to engage in personal contact with, or to allow personal contact by, employees, devices or equipment or by personnel provided by the establishment which appeals to the prurient interest of the patron, to include, but not to be limited to, bath houses, massage parlors, and related or similar activities. No part of this title will be deemed to disenfranchise any member of the healing arts licensed by the state to perform manipulation of body parts as part of their profession or counseling of said persons by licensed practitioners. 
(16)  Specified anatomical areas. 
a.  Human male or female genitals, pubic area, anal cleft or cleavage of the buttocks, or 
b.  Any portion of either the nipple of the female breast or the female vulva, or 
c.  Any portion of the male penis or the penis in a discernible erect state, even if completely or opaquely covered. 
(17)  Specified criminal activities. Prostitution or promotion of prostitution; sale, distribution or display of harmful material to a minor; sexual performance by a minor; possession or distribution of child pornography; public lewdness; indecent exposure; indecency with a child; engaged in organized criminal activity; sexual assault; molestation of a child; distribution of a controlled substance; or any offense under the criminal offense section of the Kansas Statutes. 
(18)  Specified sexual conduct/sexual activities shall include but not be limited to the following: 
a.  The fondling or other erotic touching of human or animal genitals, pubic region, buttocks, anus, or female breasts; 
b.  Sex acts, normal or perverted, actual or simulated, including intercourse, oral copulation, sodomy, and any penetration of the vagina or anus, however slight, by any body part or object; 
c.  Acts of human or animal masturbation, manual or instrumental, actual or simulated on oneself or of one person by another; and, 
d.  Excretory functions as part of or in connection with any activities set forth in subsequent subsections a. through c. of this definition. 
(Ord. No. G-975, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 42-306. - Location restrictions. 
(1)  "Adult entertainment uses" or "sexually oriented uses" as specified and defined hereinabove shall be permitted to locate only in the CP-2 and CP-3 zoning districts. 
(2)  No sexually oriented business shall be allowed within 500 feet of any other sexually oriented business as defined in this section. 
(3)  No sexually oriented business shall be allowed to locate within 500 feet of any religious institution, public or private school (compulsory education curriculum), preschool facility, hospital, or nursing or convalescent home. 
(4)  No sexually oriented business shall be allowed to locate within 300 feet of any area zoned for residential use. 
(5)  All distances required to be met pursuant to the terms of this section shall be measured in a straight line, regardless of intervening structures, from the closest exterior structural wall of the sexually oriented business to the nearest property line of the public or private school, religious institution, hospital, nursing or convalescent home, or residentially zoned lot. Required distance between two sexually oriented businesses shall be measured in a straight line, regardless of intervening structures, from the closest exterior structural wall of one sexually oriented business to the closest exterior structural wall of the other sexually oriented business. 
(6)  Nothing within these location requirements shall preclude a sexually oriented business from conducting more than one adult-use activity within a single structure, provided the adult use business shall comply with all provisions of this article and all other City ordinances. 
(7)  The location of a newly established school, religious institution, preschool facility, hospital, nursing or convalescent home, or residential zone within the required distance of an existing adult use business shall not thereby cause the existing adult use business to be deemed a non-conforming use. 
(8)  Legally established Sexually Oriented Businesses located in the CP-2 or CP-3 zoning districts on or before the effective date of this Ordinance shall not be deemed as a nonconforming use. 
(Ord. No. G-975, § 2, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 42-307. - Signage. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of the zoning code, an adult establishment shall not be permitted more than one sign advertising its business, which shall be an on-premises or building sign only. Off-premises signs are not permitted. All such signs shall meet the following criteria and the signage requirements of the Pittsburg Zoning Codes. In the event of a conflict between this section and the Pittsburg Zoning Regulations, the sexually oriented business shall comply with the more restrictive provision: 
(1)  No sign shall be placed in any window. In addition to the one sign advertising the business, a sign no larger than two square feet may be placed on the door to state hours of operation and "adults only". 
(2)  No sign shall contain any flashing lights, moving elements, or mechanically changing messages. 
(3)  No sign or exterior surface of the sexually oriented business premises, including windows and doors, shall include descriptive art, graphics, lighting or designs depicting or referring to a nude person or specified sexual activities or specified body parts. 
(4)  No sexually oriented business shall permit temporary signs, portable signs, exterior or interior window signs, or banner signs as defined in the Pittsburg Zoning Regulations. 
(5)  No merchandise, pictures of products, or pictures of entertainment on the premises shall be displayed in window areas or any area where they can be viewed from outside of the building. 
(6)  No sexually oriented business shall permit any architectural building element that draws attention to the business, including but not limited to, neon lighting outlining the building, spot lighting, strobe lighting, or garish paint. 
(7)  A sexually oriented business shall obtain a sign permit prior to installation or modification of its sign, in accordance with the Pittsburg Zoning Regulations. 
(Ord. No. G-975, § 3, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 42-308. - Licensing requirements. 
    A City of Pittsburg standard business license shall be required. 
(Ord. No. G-975, § 4, 6-28-2005)

ARTICLE II. - RECREATIONAL VEHICLES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 78. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 46-31-46-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CAMPGROUNDS 

Sec. 46-51. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this Section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Camper trailer (pop-up) means a structure designed to provide temporary living quarters for recreational, camping or travel use, constructed with integral wheels to make it mobile and/or towable by a motor vehicle, not to exceed 24 feet in length and five feet six inches in height in a collapsed condition. 
    Camping bus means a self-propelled vehicle designed and built as a bus, which has been designed with or converted into a portable dwelling used for recreation. 
    Hauling trailer means a light-duty utility trailer intended for residential use including open-bed small trailers designed to be towed behind a car or truck. 
    Motor home means a portable dwelling designed and constructed as an integral part of a self-propelled vehicle used for recreation. 
    Person means any individual, partnership, joint venture, corporation, or other business or legal entity. 
    Pickup truck camper means a structure designed primarily to be mounted on a pickup truck chassis and with sufficient equipment to render it suitable for use as a temporary dwelling for travel, recreation or vacation use. 
    Recreational vehicle means a vehicular type unit built on or for use on a chassis and designed as living quarters, both permanent and temporary, for recreational, camping and travel use, and which has its own motive power, or is mounted on, or which can be drawn or hauled by, another vehicle. The term "recreational vehicle" shall include, but not be limited to, motor homes, travel trailers, camper trailers, pickup truck campers, hauling trailers and camper buses. 
    Recreational vehicle campground means a lot, tract or parcel of land designed for occupancy by recreational vehicles for temporary or transient living purposes, including the use of camping spaces for tents. 
    Travel trailer means a structure, not to exceed nine feet in width, designed to provide temporary living quarters for recreational, camping or travel use, constructed with integral wheels to make it mobile and/or towable by a motor vehicle. 
(Code 1975, § 26-101) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 46-52. - Preliminary plan for campground; minimum requirements. 
    The applicant for a campground shall prepare or cause to be prepared a preliminary campground plan, drawn to scale not less than one inch equals 100 feet, and ten copies of the plan shall be submitted to the Planning and Zoning Commission for its review and recommendations. Such plan shall comply with the following minimum requirements: 
(1)  The plan shall contain the legal description of the boundary of the proposed campground. 
(2)  The tract to be used as a campground shall not be less than two acres in area and shall be permitted only when serviced by a public sanitary sewer and water supply system. 
(3)  Campgrounds shall, under no circumstances, be utilized for the occupancy of mobile homes. 
(4)  Elevation contours shall be indicated on the plan and shall be in accordance to City datum. 
(5)  A sewage dump station shall be provided within the campground boundary. 
(6)  The campground shall be located on a well-drained site, properly graded, where necessary, to ensure rapid drainage and freedom from stagnant pools of water. 
(7)  Sight obscuring screening of not less than six feet in height shall be provided between the campground and any adjoining residential areas. The suitability of such screening shall be determined by the Planning and Zoning Commission. 
(8)  A campground shall observe the building setback requirements for the district in which it is located. 
(9)  All roadways and vehicular parking areas must be paved with concrete or asphaltic concrete paving. 
(10)  A service building shall be provided in campgrounds exceeding 15 camping spaces. Additional buildings shall be provided for each additional 100 camping spaces. Each service building shall: 
a.  Be located within 300 feet of the campground; 
b.  Be of permanent construction; 
c.  Have one flush-type toilet, one lavatory, and one shower or bathtub for females; and one flush-type toilet, one lavatory, and one shower or bathtub for males for each 30 camping spaces; all lavatories, bathtubs, and showers shall be connected with both hot and cold running water; 
d.  Have an accessible, adequate, safe and potable supply of cold water; 
e.  Comply with all applicable adopted building codes regarding the construction of buildings and the installation of electrical, plumbing, heating and air conditioning systems; 
f.  Be maintained in a clean, sanitary condition and kept free of any condition that will menace the health of any occupants or the public or will constitute a menace. 
(Code 1975, § 26-102(a)) 
Sec. 46-53. - Approval of preliminary plan; final plan to be submitted; issuance of permit. 
    Upon approval of the preliminary campground plan by the Planning and Zoning Commission, the applicant shall prepare and submit ten copies of the final campground plan, which shall incorporate any changes or alterations requested. Upon the determination that the final campground plan accurately reflects the desires of the Planning and Zoning Commission, an approved copy shall be forwarded within seven days, to the Building Official, who may issue the required permits upon proper application. 
(Code 1975, § 26-102(b)) 
Sec. 46-54. - Zoning requirements. 
    Recreational vehicle campgrounds are only permitted in a general business district or a less restrictive zoning district. 
(Code 1975, § 26-102(c)) 
Secs. 46-55-46-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PARKING AND STORAGE 

Sec. 46-81. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this Section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Camper trailer (pop-up) means a structure designed to provide temporary living quarters for recreational, camping or travel use, constructed with integral wheels to make it mobile and/or towable by a motor vehicle, not to exceed 24 feet in length and five feet six inches in height in a collapsed condition. 
    Camping bus means a self-propelled vehicle designed and built as a bus, which has been designed with or converted into a portable dwelling used for recreation. 
    Dwelling unit means a residence consisting of a single unit providing complete, independent living facilities for one or more persons, including permanent living, sleeping, eating, cooking and sanitation. 
    Hauling trailer means a light-duty utility trailer intended for residential use including open-bed small trailers designed to be towed behind a car or truck. 
    Light truck means a motor vehicle designed, used and maintained primarily for the transportation of property and materials, but which has a manufacturer's gross weight of three-fourths ton or less and does not at any point exceed seven feet in height or 21 feet in length. 
    Light van means a van otherwise meeting the definition of a van, but which has a manufacturer's gross vehicle weight rate of three-fourths ton or less and does not at any point exceed seven feet in height or 21 feet in length. 
    Motor home means a portable dwelling designed and constructed as an integral part of a self-propelled vehicle used for recreation. 
    Permanent parking means parking on the permanent driveway or on a pad, or in the yard of any of the described recreational vehicles or recreational equipment for a period of greater than 72 hours. 
    Person means any individual, partnership, joint venture, corporation, or other business or legal entity. 
    Pickup truck camper means a structure designed primarily to be mounted on a pickup truck chassis and with sufficient equipment to render it suitable for use as a temporary dwelling for travel, recreation or vacation use. 
    Recreational equipment means that which an occupant or owner may desire for convenience to store on his lot, but which item is normally and principally transported for use off the lot on a trailer or other vehicle and which is not used by the very nature and utility of the item in connection with customary accessory residential uses of the lot. Included in the meaning of equipment are such large items as slide-in campers, boat trailers, hang gliders, ski jets, houseboats, pontoons, and boats over 14 feet in length which require a trailer for transportation. 
    Recreational vehicle means a vehicular type unit built on or for use on a chassis and designed as living quarters, both permanent and temporary, for recreational, camping and travel use, and which has its own motive power, or is mounted on, or which can be drawn or hauled by, another vehicle. The term "recreational vehicle" shall include, but not be limited to, motor homes, travel trailers, camper trailers, pickup truck campers, hauling trailers and camper buses. 
    Slide-in camper means a structure designed to be mounted temporarily or permanently in the bed of a pickup or light truck to provide enclosed storage space for transportation of property or quarters for recreational camping, including shells and truck cabs. 
    Storage means the placing of any described vehicles or recreational equipment within an enclosed structure which obscures such vehicles from view. 
    Travel trailer means a structure, not to exceed nine feet in width, designed to provide temporary living quarters for recreational, camping or travel use, constructed with integral wheels to make it mobile and/or towable by a motor vehicle. 
    Visibility triangle means the triangular area formed by the intersecting street right-of-way lines and a straight line joining such street right-of-way lines at points which are 30 feet distant from the point of intersection, measured along the right-of-way lines. 
(Code 1975, § 26-201) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 46-82. - Requirements generally. 
    Recreational vehicles and recreational equipment may be stored within single-family, two-family, multifamily, restricted multifamily, neighborhood business, residential business and planned unit development districts of the City only in accordance with the following: Recreational vehicles and recreational equipment may be stored within an enclosed structure (which structure otherwise conforms to the zoning requirements of the City), or may be permanently parked upon the private property of the premises if the recreational vehicle or recreational equipment is not parked within ten feet of any curbline or roadway and does not interfere or impede travel on any public sidewalk or thoroughfare. 
(Code 1975, § 26-202) 
Sec. 46-83. - Habitation. 
    At no time shall a permanently or temporarily parked or stored recreational vehicle or item of recreational equipment be occupied or used for living, sleeping, or housekeeping purposes except: A recreational vehicle permanently parked in compliance with this division may be occupied for sleeping purposes only, for a period not to exceed 14 consecutive calendar days in any three-month period. The Building Official or designated agent can authorize an extension of time for extenuating circumstances upon receipt of a written request. 
(Code 1975, § 26-203) 
Sec. 46-84. - Utilities. 
    A recreational vehicle or recreational equipment may be connected only to the electrical utility system. All other utilities and life support system must be disconnected when such vehicle is permanently parked. Such connection must be in accordance with the National Electrical Code, and such connection must be available for inspection during regular business hours by the Building Official or designated agent. 
(Code 1975, § 26-204) 
Sec. 46-85. - Visibility. 
    The parking of recreational vehicles and recreational equipment shall be prohibited in the visibility triangle, nor shall they be parked so as to hinder visibility of traffic. 
(Code 1975, § 26-205) 
Sec. 46-86. - Prohibited parking. 
    Recreational vehicles or recreational equipment shall not be parked on any public street or right-of-way for a period longer than 24 consecutive hours. Exceptions to the provisions of this Section are as follows: light vans, light trucks, and light trucks having a slide-in camper not extending over the top of or wider than the truck cab may park upon those streets where vehicle parking is otherwise permitted. 
(Code 1975, § 26-206) 
Sec. 46-87. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this division do not apply to those businesses displaying recreational vehicles or recreational equipment for sale or service when such business is located in a proper zoning district and licensed in accordance with City codes. 
(Code 1975, § 26-208)
