Chapter 62 - PLANNING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance adopting or amending the comprehensive plan saved from repeal, § 1-11(8); any ordinance rezoning specific property or otherwise pertaining to zoning saved from repeal, § 1-11(14); administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; community development, ch. 26; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 46; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 74; utilities, ch. 82. 
State Law reference- Planning and zoning, K.S.A. 12-715b et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 62-1. - Adoption of City comprehensive community plan. 
    To provide the City with a set of development policies, recommendations for future actions, and future land use plan, to be used by both public officials and private parties to assist them in guiding decisions dealing with land use, public programs and services, and investments in public facilities, as well as provide a basis for coordinated development so as to best promote the health, safety, morals, order, convenience, prosperity and general welfare, including the wise and efficient expenditure of public funds, the "City of Pittsburg, Kansas Comprehensive Community Plan," prepared by Wilson & Company in association with Earles & Riggs pursuant to K.S.A. 12-747, et seq., as amended by the Planning and Zoning Commission, and published in booklet form, is hereby adopted and incorporated in this Section by reference. Not less than three copies of such comprehensive community plan shall be marked or stamped "Official Copy, as adopted and incorporated by Ordinance No. G-877," to which each shall have attached a copy of this Section and be filed with the City Clerk to be open to inspection and available to the public at all reasonable hours. 
(Ord. No. G-877, § 1, 6-26-2002) 
Sec. 62-2. - Airport industrial park; violation or breach of covenants. 
    The violation or breach of any covenant or condition in the instrument, entitled "Restrictive Covenants and Conditions - Pittsburg Airport Industrial Park First Addition," shall be deemed a misdemeanor, and any person, firm, association, partnership or corporation convicted of such violation or breach shall be punished as provided in Section 1-7 of this Code for each and every violation or breach, with each day's violation or breach to constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1975, § 2-301) 
Sec. 62-3. - Restrictive covenants and conditions; Remington Square. 
    The violation or breach of any covenant or condition in the instrument entitled, "Restrictive Covenants and Conditions - Remington Square, a Replat of Lots 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, and 10 in Golden Acres Subdivision" shall be deemed a misdemeanor, and any person, firm, association, partnership or corporation convicted of such violation or breach shall be punished as provided in Section 1-7 of this Code per day for each and every violation or breach, with each day's violation or breach to constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. G-858A, § 1, 10-13-2000) 
Sec. 62-4. - Research and development park; violation or breach of covenant. 
    The violation or breach of any covenant or condition in the instrument, entitled "Restated Restrictive Covenants and Conditions - Pittsburg Research and Development Park Addition," shall be deemed a misdemeanor and any person, firm, association, partnership or corporation convicted of such violation or breach shall be punished as provided in Section 1-7 of this Code per day for each and every violation or breach, with each day's violation or breach to constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1975, § 25-301) 
Sec. 62-5. - Restrictive covenants and conditions; Pittsburg Airport Industrial Park West Addition. 
    The violation or breaching of any covenant or condition in the instrument, entitled "Restrictive Covenants and Conditions, Pittsburg Airport Industrial Park West Addition," shall be deemed a misdemeanor and any person, firm, association, partnership or corporation convicted of such violation or breach shall be punished as provided in Section 1-7 of this Code per day for each and every violation or breach, with each day's violation or breach to constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. G-891, § 1, 11-13-2001) 
Secs. 62-6-62-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLANNING COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and authorities, § 2-311 et seq. 
State Law reference- Planning commissions, K.S.A. 12-744 et seq. 

Sec. 62-41. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created a Planning Commission. It shall consist of seven members appointed by the Governing Body. Five of the members must be residents of the City, and two of the members shall reside outside of but within three miles of the corporate limits of the City. The members of the Planning Commission shall also serve as the members of the Board of Zoning Appeals and shall serve the term for which they were appointed by the Governing Body. Upon the expiration of the term of any member, the Governing Body shall appoint that member or some other qualified individual to a three year term of office; provided, however, that no members shall serve more than two consecutive terms. 
(Code 1975, § 24-101; Ord. No. G-1265, § 1, 11-22-2016) 
Sec. 62-42. - Filling vacancies. 
    Should any member of the Planning Commission resign, move to an area other than the area they were appointed to represent, or be removed by the Governing Body, the Governing Body shall appoint some other qualified individual to serve the former member's unexpired term. 
(Code 1975, § 24-102) 
Sec. 62-43. - Election of officers. 
    The members of the Planning Commission shall annually elect one of its own members as chairperson and another as vice-chairperson, each of whom shall serve for one year and until successors are appointed. 
(Code 1975, § 24-103) 
Sec. 62-44. - Meetings. 
    The Planning Commission shall meet at least once a month at a time and place as fixed by resolution. Special meetings may be called by the chairperson or, in his absence, the vice-chairperson. The commission shall cause a proper record to be kept of its proceedings. A copy of such proceedings shall be signed by the secretary and filed with the City Clerk. All affidavits for legal notices published by the Planning Commission shall be filed with the City Clerk. 
(Code 1975, § 24-104) 
Sec. 62-45. - Powers and duties. 
    The Planning Commission shall be vested with such powers and charged with such duties as are enumerated in the zoning ordinance and subdivision regulations, or may hereafter be fixed, by the laws of the state. 
(Code 1975, § 24-105) 
State Law reference- Planning Commission powers generally, K.S.A. 12-745 et seq. 
Secs. 62-46-62-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ZONING ORDINANCE[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Zoning, K.S.A. 12-753 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 62-81. - Zoning ordinance of City adopted. 
    To preserve property values, ensure that adequate access and space is available between dwellings and buildings, help to guide orderly growth, set forth land use objectives, and adopt reasonable rules and regulations so as to further promote the public health, safety, comfort, convenience, and general welfare of the citizens of the City, the "Zoning Ordinance of Pittsburg, Kansas," including the zoning district maps and overlays, prepared by Burns and McDonnell Engineering Company, Inc., is hereby adopted and incorporated in this Section by reference. Not less than three copies of the zoning ordinance shall be marked or stamped "Official Copy, as adopted by Ordinance No. G-663," and to which shall be attached a copy of this Section and filed with the City Clerk to be open to inspection and available to the public at all reasonable hours. The Police Department, the municipal court judge, and all administrative departments of the City charged with the enforcement of the zoning ordinance shall be supplied, at the cost of the City, such number of official copies of such zoning ordinance similarly marked as may be deemed expedient. 
(Code 1975, § 24-301) 
Sec. 62-82. - Abatement of violation. 
    In case any building or structure is or is proposed to be erected, constructed, reconstructed, moved, altered, converted, or maintained, or any building, structure, or land is or is proposed to be used in violation of the zoning ordinance, the zoning administrator, City Attorney, or other appropriate authority of the City may, in addition to all other remedies, institute injunction, mandamus, or other appropriate action or proceedings to prevent such unlawful erection, construction, reconstruction, relocation, alteration, conversion, maintenance, or use, or to correct or abate such violation, or to prevent the occupancy of a building, structure, or land. 
(Code 1975, § 24-302) 
State Law reference- Abatement of violations, K.S.A. 12-761(c). 
Sec. 62-83. - Fees. 
    The fees listed in this Section shall be charged as follows: 
(1)  Zoning ordinance amendment, change in zoning, district boundary map or conditional use permit: $185.00. 
(2)  The vacation of a street, alley or easement: $125.00. 
(Ord. No. G-1085, § 1, 1-26-2010; Ord. No. G-1154, § 1, 9-13-2011) 
Sec. 62-84. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person or corporation who shall violate any of the provisions of the zoning ordinance or fail to comply herewith, or with any of the requirements thereof; or who shall build or alter any building in violation of any detailed statement or plan submitted and approved hereunder shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. The owner of a building or premises or part thereof, where anything in violation of the zoning ordinance shall be placed, or shall exist, and any architect, builder, contractor, agent, person or corporation employed in connection therewith, and who assisted in the commission of any such violation, shall be guilty of a separate offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to the same fine as provided in this Section. 
(Code 1975, § 24-303) 
State Law reference- Penalty for zoning ordinance violations, K.S.A. 12-761(c). 
Secs. 62-85-62-100. - Reserved.

Sec. 62-101. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created a Board of Zoning Appeals. It shall consist of seven members appointed by the Governing Body. Five members must be residents of the City, and two of the members shall reside outside of but within three miles of the corporate limits of the City. The members of the Board of Zoning Appeals shall also serve as the members of the Planning Commission and shall serve the term for which they were appointed by the Governing Body. Upon the expiration of the term of any member, the Governing Body shall appoint that member or some other qualified individual to a three-year term of office; provided, however, that no members shall serve more than two consecutive terms. 
(Code 1975, § 24-201; Ord. No. G-1265, § 2, 11-22-2016)

    Should any member of the Board of Zoning Appeals resign, move from the City, or be removed by the Governing Body, the Governing Body shall appoint some other qualified individual to serve the former member's unexpired term. 
(Code 1975, § 24-202) 
Sec. 62-103. - Election of officers. 
    The members of the Board of Zoning Appeals shall annually elect one of its own members as chairperson and another as vice-chairperson, each of whom shall serve for one year and until successors are appointed. 
(Code 1975, § 24-203) 
Sec. 62-104. - Powers and duties. 
    The Board of Zoning Appeals shall be vested with such powers and charged with such duties as are enumerated in the zoning ordinance or the laws of the state, as well as all amendments and modifications thereto. 
(Code 1975, § 24-204) 
Sec. 62-105. - Meetings. 
    The Board of Zoning Appeals shall meet at a time and place pursuant to the call of the chairperson or vice-chairperson in the absence of the chairperson. 
(Code 1975, § 24-205) 
Sec. 62-106. - Fees for hearing. 
    The fee listed in this Section shall be charged as follows: Filing fee for hearing before the Board of Zoning Appeals for variances or special exceptions: $125.00. 
(Ord. No. G-1085, § 2, 1-26-2010; Ord. No. G-1154, § 2, 9-13-2011)

Sec. 62-141. - Subdivision ordinance adopted. 
    To preserve property values, ensure that adequate access and space is available between dwellings and buildings, help to guide orderly growth, set forth land use objectives, and adopt reasonable rules and regulations so as to further promote the public health, safety, comfort, convenience, and general welfare of the citizens of the City, the "Pittsburg Subdivision Ordinance," prepared by Burns and McDonnell Engineering Company, Inc., is hereby adopted and incorporated in this Section by reference. Not less than three copies of the Pittsburg Subdivision Ordinance shall be marked or stamped "Official Copy, as adopted by Ordinance No. G-664," and to which shall be attached a copy of this Section and filed with the City Clerk to be open to inspection and available to the public at all reasonable hours. The Police Department, the municipal court judge, and all administrative departments of the City charged with the enforcement of the zoning ordinance shall be supplied, at the cost of the City, such number of official copies of such Pittsburg Subdivision Ordinance similarly marked as may be deemed expedient.

Sec. 62-143. - Penalty for violation.

The Governing Body shall further have the authority to maintain suits or actions in any court of competent jurisdiction for the purpose of enforcing any provisions of the subdivision ordinance and to abate nuisances maintained in violation thereof, and in addition to other remedies, institute injunction, mandamus, or other appropriate action or proceedings to prevent such unlawful erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, conversion, maintenance or use, or to correct or abate such violation or to prevent the occupancy of any building, structure or land. 
(Code 1975, § 24-402) 
State Law reference- Penalty for violation of subdivision regulations, K.S.A. 12-761. 
Secs. 62-144-62-149. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - DOWNTOWN ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 62-150. - Creation; membership, terms. 
    It is hereby declared to be in the best interests of the City to create a Downtown Advisory Board (DAB) to be composed of seven members appointed by the Governing Body, all of whom are to selected for their wisdom, ability, and interest in issues related to "Downtown Pittsburg", defined as the Downtown Overlay (DO) District. Criteria for membership is as follows: one member will represent the hospitality industry; one member will represent the retail industry; one member will be a property owner; one member will live in the DO District; and three members will be at large with a vested interest in the DO District. The three at large members will serve an initial one-year term and the remaining four members will serve two-year terms. Following the expiration of the initial terms of the three members at large, these members will thereafter be appointed to two-year terms. Residence within the city limits shall not be a requirement of membership except for the one member who must reside in the DO District. 
(Ord. No. G-1243, § 1, 12-8-2015) 
Sec. 62-151. - Election of officers. 
    The members of the Downtown Advisory Board shall annually appoint one Board member as chairperson and another Board member as vice-chairperson, each of whom shall serve for one year and until successors are appointed. 
(Ord. No. G-1243, § 1, 12-8-2015) 
Sec. 62-152. - Ex-officio member; secretary. 
    The City Manager or his or her designee shall be an ex-officio member of the Board and shall act as secretary and keep minutes, but shall not be entitled to vote on any matter considered by the Board. 
(Ord. No. G-1243, § 1, 12-8-2015) 
Sec. 62-153. - Filling of vacancies; removal; quorum. 
    Upon the expiration of the term of any member, the Governing Body shall either reappoint that member, or some other qualified individual for a two-year term of membership; provided, however, that no member shall serve more than three consecutive terms. Any member may be removed by the Governing Body for failing to attend meetings of the Downtown Advisory Board or for no longer meeting the criteria for service. Should any member of the Downtown Advisory Board resign, pass away, or be removed by the Governing Body, the Governing Body shall appoint some other qualified individual to serve the former member's unexpired term. Four members of the Downtown Advisory Board shall constitute a quorum. An affirmative vote of the majority of a quorum shall be required for any action taken by the Board. 
(Ord. No. G-1243, § 1, 12-8-2015) 
Sec. 62-154. - Advisory Board duties. 
    The Downtown Advisory Board shall act as a deliberative and review body representing the interests of downtown property owners, residents and merchants (the downtown community). The Downtown Advisory Board shall establish committees as agreed upon by the Board and provide oversight of these committees. The Board will review the decisions, requests, and recommendations of the committees and make final decisions. When appropriate, the Board will request the City Manager, or his or her designee, to present a decision, request or recommendation to the Governing Body. One Board member will be responsible for each Committee, based on expertise and interest, and will report the decisions, requests, and recommendations of the Committee to the Board. 
(Ord. No. G-1243, § 1, 12-8-2015) 
Sec. 62-155. - Committee duties. 
    The appropriate committee will be responsible for the following: 
a.  Reviewing and making recommendations regarding plans proposed in the DO District prior to submission to the Planning and Zoning Commission. 
b.  Consult, advise, or otherwise support current and incoming business owners regarding City and DO District regulations and processes. 
c.  Assist in resolving conflicts within the downtown community. Individuals owning property, businesses, or a primary residence within the DO District will be eligible to have their issues placed on the agenda of the next scheduled meeting of the appropriate committee. 
d.  Make recommendations to the Downtown Advisory Board regarding issues related to development and activities with the DO District. 
(Ord. No. G-1243, § 1, 12-8-2015) 
Sec. 62-156. - Operational processes; meeting frequency; annual report. 
    The Downtown Advisory Board may adopt, define and amend its operational processes, in writing, and shall submit the same to the City Clerk. The Board shall meet at least quarterly at a time and place as fixed by the chairperson. Special meetings may be called by the chairperson or, in his or her absence, the vice-chairperson. The City Manager or his designee may call a meeting if exigent circumstances require timely action by the Board. The Board chairperson, without a formal meeting of the Board and upon consulting with the other members, may provide a formal response of "No comment" if a response from the Board is requested. 
    The Downtown Advisory Board, with input from the Committees, shall prepare an annual report in March of each year. The DAB Chairperson will present the annual report during a work session with the City Commission to review the accomplishments and goals of the Committees and Advisory Board. Following such a review, if the Governing Body finds it is in the best interest of the City, the Downtown Advisory Board may be dissolved by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. G-1243, § 1, 12-8-2015) 
Secs. 62-157-62-159. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SUSTAINABILITY ADVISORY COMMITTEE 

Sec. 62-160. - Creation; membership. 
    It is hereby declared to be in the best interests of the City to create a Sustainability Advisory Committee to be composed of seven members appointed by the governing body, all of whom are to be selected for their wisdom, ability, and interest in issues related to sustainability issues, programs and practices in the City. The members shall each serve a two-year term of office, and all members shall have an interest in the promotion and establishment of sustainability, issues, programs and practices. 
(Ord. No. G-1281, § 1, 5-8-2018) 
Sec. 62-161. - Election of officers. 
    The members of the Sustainability Advisory Committee shall annually elect one of its own members as chairperson and another as vice-chairperson, each of whom shall serve for one year and until successors are appointed. 
(Ord. No. G-1281, § 1, 5-8-2018) 
Sec. 62-162. - Ex-officio member; secretary. 
    The City Manager or his or her designee shall be an ex-officio member of the Committee and shall act as secretary and keep minutes, but shall not be entitled to vote on any matter considered by the Committee. 
(Ord. No. G-1281, § 1, 5-8-2018) 
Sec. 62-163. - Filling of vacancies; removal; quorum. 
    Upon the expiration of the term of any member, the governing body shall elect that member or some other qualified individual to a two-year term of office; provided, however, that no member shall serve more than three consecutive terms. Any member may be removed by the governing body for failing to attend meetings of the Sustainability Advisory Committee or for no longer meeting the criteria for service. Should any member of the Sustainability Commission resign, pass away, or be removed by the governing body, the governing body shall appoint some other qualified individual to serve the former member's unexpired term. Three members of the Sustainability Advisory Committee shall constitute a quorum. 
(Ord. No. G-1281, § 1, 5-8-2018) 
Sec. 62-164. - Functions. 
    The Sustainability Advisory Committee shall perform the following functions: 
(1)  Monitor and review environmental protection, waste reduction, recycling, energy conservation and natural resource conservation efforts of the City. 
(2)  Assist the governing body and city staff to develop and establish goals and priorities for future environmental protection, waste reduction, recycling, energy conservation and natural resource conservation efforts of the City. 
(3)  Advise the governing body and the city staff on practical methods and programs to reach the goals for future environmental protection, waste reduction, recycling, energy conservation and natural resource conservation efforts of the City. 
(4)  Assist the governing body and city staff to identify and pursue potential funding sources and options for environmental protection, waste reduction, recycling, energy conservation and natural resource conservation efforts of the City. 
(5)  Serve as a liaison to other City boards and committees on sustainability issues, programs, and practices. 
(6)  Educate and promote sustainability practices and programs and foster community participation for sustainability practices and programs. 
(Ord. No. G-1281, § 1, 5-8-2018) 
Sec. 62-165. - Operational processes; meeting frequency. 
    The Sustainability Advisory Committee may adopt, define and amend its operational processes, in writing, and shall submit the same to the City Clerk. The Committee shall meet at least quarterly at a time and place as fixed by the chairperson. Special meetings may be called by the chairperson or, in his or her absence, the vice-chairperson. 
(Ord. No. G-1281, § 1, 5-8-2018) 
Chapter 66 - RAILROADS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Railroads generally, K.S.A. 66-201 et seq. 

Sec. 66-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this Section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Railway company means every person, partnership, or corporation owning, leasing, controlling or operating a railway or railroad, in the City. 
    Street means street, avenue, road, alley, or any other public highway. 
(Code 1975, § 16-101) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 66-2. - Crossings maintenance or construction. 
(a)  Drainage required. Every railway company which operates on or controls any railway tracks that cross any public street in the City shall provide, at the intersection of its tracks with each street, drains sufficient to carry off the water which may run down such streets along the ditches or gutters thereof, and such railway company shall not obstruct such ditches or gutters so as to prevent the flow of water therein. 
(b)  Maintenance. It shall be the duty of every railway company controlling or operating any railroad within the City to construct and maintain suitable crossings over the tracks, and such crossings shall be maintained in a passable condition so that vehicles can cross such railroad tracks with ease and without difficulty. 
(c)  Crossings; paving required. It shall be the duty of any railway company whose railroad tracks crosses any public street of the City to pave between the tracks and between the rails of such railroad and for a distance of at least three feet outside of such rails, in any street upon which tracks are located, with the same kind and quality of material with which such street is paved or with such material as may be approved by the Director of Public Works. 
(d)  Grade of rails. Every railway company which has heretofore constructed or shall hereafter construct or repair railway tracks upon, across or along any public street in the City, shall construct, repair or reconstruct such tracks so as to make the top of the rails of the same level with the grade of the street established by the City. 
(e)  Failure to comply; City may do work. In case any railway company shall fail, neglect or refuse to comply with subsections (a)-(d) of this Section, within 20 days after notice in writing so to do has been served upon the agent of the railway company by the Director of Public Works, then such drains, maintenance, paving, repairing or leveling of tracks, rails or crossings may be done by the City, and the cost of such improvements shall be a lien upon the property of such railway company and may be assessed and taxed against the property of such railway company in the same manner as other taxes are levied against railway property. In addition thereto, if the Governing Body so directs, such amounts due the City may be enforced and collected by suit in any court having jurisdiction. 
(Code 1975, §§ 16-102-16-106) 
State Law reference- Failure to maintain railroad crossings, K.S.A. 66-228. 
Sec. 66-3. - Flagperson or signals required. 
(a)  Required. It shall be the duty of every railway company, if the tracks crossing a public street are not protected by properly functioning flashing light signal controls, at all street crossings where the vision of pedestrians or users of the street of an approaching train, engine or rail car is obstructed due to weeds, trees, vegetation or buildings or due to rail cars, engines or trains parked within 150 feet of the crossing, to have a flagperson warn such pedestrians or users of the street of the approach of any train, engine or rail car by flashing a plainly visible warning device. 
(b)  Employees; violations. It shall be unlawful for any engineer, conductor, brakeman, or any other employee of a railway company to run or operate or assist in running or operating or to give any order or orders to run or operate any rail car or train of cars or any engine or engines across any street in the City without a flagperson being at such crossings in accordance with this Section. 
(c)  Neglect of duty. It shall be unlawful for any individual employed as flagperson to fail, neglect or refuse to perform any of the duties provided in this Section for such flagperson. 
(Code 1975, §§ 16-107-16-109) 
Sec. 66-4. - Rate of speed. 
    It shall be unlawful for the employee of any railway company to operate or control any train, engine or rail car at a speed in excess of the published track classification listed by the Federal Railroad Administration's Track Safety Standards, as amended; provided, however, that it shall also be unlawful for the employee of any railway company, in charge of the operation or control of any train, engine or rail car, to fail to activate the braking system to reduce the speed of such train, engine, or rail car when the life or limb of any person is in imminent danger or by reason of weather or track conditions which make it unsafe to operate the train, engine or rail car. 
(Code 1975, § 16-110) 
Sec. 66-5. - Obstruction of crossing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any employee of a railway company having charge or control of an engine, rail car or train to cause or permit the same to remain standing on or to obstruct the passage over any public street crossing for a longer period than ten minutes at any one time; provided, however, that this Section shall have no application to a continuously moving train or appliances activated thereby which because of its length cannot reasonably pass over the public crossing with the time prescribed in this Section. 
(1)  For purposes of this Section, a train and appliances activated thereby which are engaged in switching operations shall not constitute a moving train. 
(2)  It shall be a defense to a charge of violation of this Section that such obstruction or standing was unavoidable due to emergency, the avoidance of accident, or other situation where the railroad company was not at fault. 
(Code 1975, § 16-111) 
State Law reference- Obstruction of railroad crossing, K.S.A. 66-273. 
Sec. 66-6. - Warning whistle required. 
    It shall be the duty of each employee of a railway company having the control or charge of any train, engine or rail car to sound a plainly audible warning whistle when approaching any public crossing and to repeat such sounding until the crossing is occupied by the train engine or rail car. 
(Code 1975, § 16-112) 
State Law reference- Required whistles, K.S.A. 66-2120. 
Chapter 70 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Regulating disposal of animal carcass, § 10-149; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 46; utilities, ch. 82. 
State Law reference- Solid waste, K.S.A. 65-3401 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 70-1-70-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to provide for storage, collection, transportation, processing and disposal of solid waste, K.S.A. 65-3410. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 70-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this Section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Administrative authority means the department, division or person within the City designated by the City Manager to administer this article. 
    Bulky rubbish means items of refuse too large to be placed in refuse storage containers including, but not limited to, appliances, furniture, tires, large auto parts, motor vehicles, trees, branches, or stumps. 
    Collection means the removal of solid waste from its place or storage to the transportation vehicle. 
    Commercial generator means any person engaged in an institutional, commercial, manufacturing, industrial or agricultural establishment, including other nonresidential activity that generates solid waste. 
    Compost means a controlled process of microbial degradation of organic material into a stable, nuisance-free, humus-like product. 
    Construction and demolition waste means waste building materials and rubble resulting from construction, remodeling, repair, or demolition operations of houses, commercial, industrial and agricultural buildings, other structures, and pavements. 
    Dwelling unit means any room or group of rooms located within a building or part thereof forming a single habitable unit with facilities which are used or intended to be used for living, sleeping, cooking and eating. 
    Garbage means animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, processing, storage, packaging, preparation, sale, cooking, or serving of meat, produce or other foods and shall include unclean containers. 
    Hazardous waste means, but is not limited to, medical waste, pathological waste, infectious waste, explosive waste, pesticides, pesticide containers, and toxic or radioactive materials. 
    Leachate means the liquid produced when solid waste material comes in contact with water or rainfall. 
    Licensed solid waste collector means a person who has satisfied the licensing requirements of this article in order to collect, transport and dispose of solid waste. 
    Multiple-family dwelling means a building or part thereof, containing three or more dwelling units. 
    Occupant means any person who, alone or with others, shall be in actual possession of any dwelling unit or of any other improved real property, either as owner or as a tenant. 
    Processing means incinerating, composting, bailing, shredding, salvaging, compacting and other processes, whereby solid waste characteristics are modified or solid waste quantity is reduced. 
    Recyclable material means post-consumer residential solid waste and post-consumer and preconsumer commercial solid waste, not including yard waste which can be recycled. 
    Recycling means the separation and reuse of material which might otherwise be disposed of as solid waste. 
    Refuse means solid waste. 
    Solid waste means unwanted or discarded waste materials in a solid or semisolid state including, but not limited to, putrescible and nonputrescible garbage, ashes, bulky rubbish, rubbish, dead animals, animals or agricultural wastes, yard wastes, discarded white goods, special industrial wastes, and demolition and construction wastes. Excluded from this definition is compost and recyclable materials that are separated or segregated from the solid waste. 
(1)  Commercial solid waste. Solid waste, except for industrial solid waste, generated by a commercial generator. This category includes, but is not limited to, solid waste originating in stores, markets, office buildings, restaurants, shopping centers, and theaters as well as from agricultural establishments. 
(2)  Residential solid waste. Solid waste resulting from the maintenance and operation of dwelling units. 
(3)  Industrial solid waste. Solid waste resulting from manufacturing and industrial processes which are not suitable for discharge to a sanitary sewer or treatment in a community sewage treatment plant. Industrial solid wastes may include mining wastes from the extraction, bentification and processing of ores and minerals unless those materials are returned to the mine site; fly ash, bottom ash, slag, and flue gas emission control wastes generated primarily from the combustion of coal or other fossil fuels; and cement kiln dust. 
    Solid waste container means a receptacle used by any person to store solid waste during the interval between solid waste collections. 
    Solid waste disposal means the process of discarding or getting rid of unwanted material; in particular, the final disposition of solid waste. 
    Solid waste management means the entire solid waste system of storage, collection, transportation, processing and disposal. 
    Storage means the keeping, maintaining or storing solid waste from the time of its production until the time of its collection. 
    Transportation means the transporting of solid waste from the place of collection or processing to a solid waste processing facility or solid waste disposal area. 
    Two-family dwelling means a building or portion thereof, containing two dwelling units. 
    White goods means household appliances including, but not limited to, televisions, dishwashers, washers, dryers and refrigerators. 
    Yard waste means grass clippings, leaves, and tree, shrub and brush trimmings. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 1, 9-12-2000) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 70-32. - Prohibited acts. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Deposit solid waste in any solid waste container other than that person's own without the written consent of the owner of such container. 
(2)  Maliciously prevent solid waste collection or transportation of solid waste. 
(3)  Burn garbage, greasy or oily paper, roofing materials, tar paper, tires or other heavy smoke producing material. 
(4)  Burn brush, hay, straw, leaves, grass, weeds, paper, shaving or other combustible material without an open burn permit unless burned in a safety enclosure constructed of brick, cement, stone or metal with openings covered with steel netting, one-half inch mesh or with steel plate with no larger than one-half inch holes, and only between the hours of 2:00 p.m. and 7:00 p.m. 
(5)  Dispose of solid waste at any facility or location which is not approved by the state Department of Health and Environment, or other appropriate state licensing or regulatory agency if the facility is located in the state. 
(6)  Engage in the business of collecting solid waste and/or recyclable material within the corporate limits of the City and transporting, processing or disposing of such solid waste and recyclable material without first receiving a license from the City, or after a license has been suspended or revoked. 
(7)  Remove any recyclable material from another person's solid waste container without their permission, unless such individual is licensed by the City and under contract to such person to remove such recyclable material. 
(8)  Place, leave, dump or permit to accumulate any solid waste in any building or on any premises, improved or vacant, or on any open lot, alley or public right-of-way in the City unless the solid waste is properly deposited and stored in a solid waste container. 
(9)  Fail to remove the solid waste container from the curbside or street edge to the residential premises by 12:00 p.m. noon following the day of collection. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 2, 9-12-2000) 
Sec. 70-33. - Commercial incinerator. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of Section 70-32, burning of garbage, greasy or oily paper, and medical waste may be allowed in a commercial gas-fired closed vessel type incinerator approved by the CSA International, when allowed by the state Department of Health and Environment or other state and federal regulatory agencies, and approved by the administrative authority. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 3, 9-12-2000) 
Sec. 70-34. - Transportation. 
    All vehicles used for the transportation of solid waste shall be maintained in a safe, clean and sanitary condition, and shall be so constructed, maintained and operated as to prevent spillage of solid waste therefrom. All vehicles used for transportation of solid waste which contain semiliquid or leachate shall be constructed with watertight bodies. All vehicles used for the transportation of solid waste shall have covers of suitable material with fasteners designed to secure all sides of the cover to the vehicle, which shall be secured whenever the vehicle is transporting solid waste, or the entire body shall be enclosed, with only loading hoppers exposed. No solid waste shall be transported in the loading hoppers. Vehicles used for the transportation of trees, tree limbs, brush or other foliage shall be constructed in such a way as to secure all items within or upon the vehicle with no portion thereof extending more than three feet beyond the vehicle. All vehicles to be used to transport recyclable materials shall be constructed in such a way as to prevent any of the transported material from being released from the vehicle during transit. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 28, 9-12-2000) 
Sec. 70-35. - Disposal. 
    Solid waste shall be deposited at a processing facility or disposal area complying with all requirements of the state, or any applicable law of the state where the processing facility or disposal area is located, and any applicable federal law, rule or regulation. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 29, 9-12-2000) 
Sec. 70-36. - Hazardous waste. 
    The administrative authority may classify certain wastes as hazardous wastes which will require special handling and shall be disposed of only in a manner acceptable to the administrative authority and which will meet all local, state and federal regulations. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 30, 9-12-2000) 
Secs. 70-37-70-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONTAINERS 

Sec. 70-61. - Adequate required. 
    The occupant of every dwelling unit and every commercial generator producing solid waste within the corporate limits of the City shall provide sufficient and adequate containers for the storage of all solid waste ordinarily accumulated at such place during the intervals between collection; which containers shall be maintained in good repair. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 4, 9-12-2000) 
Sec. 70-62. - Placement of solid waste in. 
    The occupant of every dwelling unit and every commercial generator shall place all solid waste to be collected in proper solid waste containers, except yard waste, bulky rubbish and construction and demolition waste, and shall maintain such solid waste containers and the area surrounding them in a clean, neat and sanitary condition at all times. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 5, 9-12-2000) 
Sec. 70-63. - For residential solid waste. 
    Residential solid waste shall be stored in containers of not less than 20 gallons in nominal capacity. Containers shall be fitted with a lid and shall be properly covered at all times except when depositing waste therein or removing the contents thereof. The container shall be of sturdy construction. Galvanized metal containers, or rubber, fiberglass or plastic containers which do not become brittle in cold weather, may be used. Disposable solid waste containers with suitable frames or containers as approved by the administrative authority may also be used for storage of residential solid waste. The occupant of every dwelling unit and two-family dwelling units shall keep the solid waste containers and area surrounding them in a clean, neat and sanitary condition. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 6, 9-12-2000) 
Sec. 70-64. - For commercial and industrial solid waste. 
    Commercial and industrial solid waste shall be stored in solid waste containers as approved by the administrative authority. The containers shall be covered at all times except when depositing waste therein or removing the contents thereof. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 7, 9-12-2000) 
Sec. 70-65. - For bulky rubbish and construction and demolition waste. 
    Containers used for bulky rubbish and construction and demolition waste shall be covered at all times during transportation. The cover may be constructed of metal, canvas, vinyl, netting or other material approved by the administrative authority. No person shall place paper, cardboard, light weight plastic or other solid waste which has the potential for becoming airborne or any material that has the potential of becoming leachate in an uncovered bulky rubbish container. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 8, 9-12-2000) 
Sec. 70-66. - Unapproved. 
    Containers other than those authorized by Sections 70-63, 70-64 and 70-65 shall be collected, together along with their contents, and disposed of. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 9, 9-12-2000) 
Sec. 70-67. - Multifamily dwellings. 
    The owners of all multiple-family dwellings shall purchase or contract with a licensed solid waste collector for an adequate container to be placed on the site for disposal of tenants' solid waste, and contract with a licensed solid waste collector for the collection, transportation and disposal of such solid waste pursuant to this article. The solid waste container must be placed on a pad of sufficient strength to hold the weight of a fully loaded container, with all new solid waste container pads to be screened. The owners of such premises shall keep the solid waste containers and the area surrounding them in a clean, neat and sanitary condition at all times and shall maintain the container screening in good repair. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 10, 9-12-2000) 
Sec. 70-68. - Storage. 
    Residential solid waste containers shall be stored behind the front of the building housing the dwelling unit and upon the private property of the residential premises. Commercial solid waste containers shall be stored upon private property, unless the owner shall have been granted written permission from the City to use public property for such purposes. The storage site shall be well drained and fully accessible to collection equipment, public health personnel and fire inspection personnel. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 11, 9-12-2000) 
Secs. 70-69-70-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - COLLECTION 

Sec. 70-91. - Failure to contract for service unlawful; enforcement by rules and regulations; and penalty for failure to comply. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the occupant or owner of every dwelling and two family dwelling, and the owner of every multiple-family dwelling, to fail to contract or otherwise agree with a licensed solid waste collector to collect all solid waste generated thereby at least once every seven days. 
(b)  The administrative authority shall establish rules and regulations to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(c)  Any person found guilty of violating this article shall, upon conviction, be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 12, 9-12-2000; Ord. No. G-1178, § 1, 2-26-2013) 
Sec. 70-92. - Commercial and industrial generator. 
    Each commercial and industrial generator shall provide for the proper collection of solid waste, and that service shall be maintained by either the owner with vehicles as required by Section 70-34, or by contract with a licensed solid waste collector. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 13, 9-12-2000) 
Sec. 70-93. - Regulations and fees. 
    All solid waste generated from premises in the City collected by the licensed solid waste collector shall be subject to the rules and regulations of the administrative authority, or subject to such rules and regulations of the licensed solid waste collector as approved by the administrative authority, except as otherwise provided in this article. All solid waste placed at the curb, or other area of collection, shall remain the property of the occupant until collected by the licensed solid waste collector. Service fees for the collection, transportation and disposal of solid waste may be established by the licensed solid waste collector providing the service and may be billed and collected by such collector. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 14, 9-12-2000) 
Sec. 70-94. - Placement. 
    Solid waste containers, as required by this article for the storage of residential solid waste, shall be placed at the curb, street edge or alley for collection. Any solid waste containers or other solid waste permitted by this article to be placed at the curb or street edge for collection shall not be so placed until the regularly scheduled collection day or the evening before. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 15, 9-12-2000) 
Sec. 70-95. - Bulky rubbish, construction and demolition waste, and white goods. 
    Bulky rubbish, construction and demolition waste, and white goods, upon request, shall be collected by a licensed solid waste collector, who shall establish the procedures for collecting bulky rubbish, construction and demolition waste, and white goods pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 16, 9-12-2000) 
Sec. 70-96. - Entry on private property by collectors. 
    Licensed solid waste collectors are hereby authorized to enter upon private property of their contracting solid waste customers for the purpose of collecting solid waste therefrom as required by this article. Licensed solid waste collectors shall not enter dwelling units or other residential buildings for the purpose of collecting residential solid waste without authorization. Commercial solid waste may be removed from within commercial establishments upon written request and approval of the owner. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 17, 9-12-2000) 
Sec. 70-97. - Schedule. 
    The administrative authority shall establish routes and schedules for the collection and transportation of residential solid waste other than bulky rubbish. All residential solid waste shall be collected on the day the route is scheduled to be collected. Except when the scheduled day for collection for a route falls on a legal holiday, the licensed solid waste collector may collect on an alternate day. No provision of this article shall prevent a licensed solid waste collector from scheduling collections of residential solid waste, yard waste and bulky rubbish, construction and demolition waste, and white goods on a more frequent basis than once every seven days. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 18, 9-12-2000) 
Sec. 70-98. - Frequencies. 
    All residential solid waste, other than bulky rubbish, construction and demolition waste, or white goods, shall be collected at least once every seven days. All commercial generator solid waste shall be collected at least once every seven days, or at more frequent intervals if directed by the administrative authority. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 19, 9-12-2000) 
Sec. 70-99. - Duty of collectors to clean up spilled waste. 
    All licensed solid waste collectors shall be responsible for the solid waste, bulky rubbish, construction and demolition waste, and white goods from the point of collection to disposal of the solid waste at the collection facility or disposal area, provided that such material was stored in compliance with Sections 70-63-70-65. Any spillage or blowing litter caused as a result of the duties of the licensed solid waste collector shall be collected and placed in the transportation vehicle by the licensed solid waste collector. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 20, 9-12-2000) 
Secs. 70-100-70-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - LICENSING OF COLLECTORS, HAULERS AND TRANSPORTERS 

Sec. 70-121. - License required. 
    No person shall collect, transport or haul over any of the streets or alleys of the City or dispose of any solid waste accumulated in the City without first receiving a license issued by the City, except this Section shall not be construed to apply to individuals collecting, transporting or hauling their own household solid waste and/or recyclable materials to a facility licensed by the state to receive such solid waste and/or recyclable materials, the street department or other departments of the City, nor to tree trimmers or tree surgeons; provided, however, that all such persons shall comply with all regulations provided by this article for the transportation of solid waste over the streets and alleys. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 21, 9-12-2000) 
Sec. 70-122. - Application. 
    Each person required by this article to be licensed to collect or remove solid waste within the City shall file with the Department of Finance an application for such license in such form as shall be prescribed. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 22, 9-12-2000; Ord. No. G-1177, § 9, 2-12-2013) 
Sec. 70-123. - Conditions precedent to issuance of license. 
    No license to collect or remove solid waste within the City shall be issued until: 
(1)  The vehicle to be licensed and operated under the license applied for shall be inspected and approved by the Police Department as to compliance with City ordinances and state statutes relating to equipment and operation of motor vehicles. 
(2)  The vehicle to be licensed and operated under the license applied for shall be inspected and approved by the Police Department as to being properly constructed and equipped for compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 23, 9-12-2000) 
Sec. 70-124. - Issuance of license. 
    The Department of Finance, upon recommendation of the Police Department, shall issue a license to persons qualified under the provisions of this article to collect or remove solid waste within the City in the manner and upon the conditions of this article. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 24, 9-12-2000; Ord. No. G-1177, § 10, 2-12-2013) 
Sec. 70-125. - License fees; term of license. 
    The following fees shall be paid in advance by the applicant for a license to collect or remove solid waste from the City for a period of one year commencing January 1 and expiring December 31. No fee shall be refunded. 
Motor vehicles 
Each truck rated at 30,000 pounds gross weight or less: As established by ordinance. 
Each truck rated in excess of 30,000 pounds gross weight: As established by ordinance. 
For each two-wheel or four-wheel trailer: As established by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 27, 9-12-2000; Ord. No. G-976, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 70-126. - Registration licenses for vehicles. 
    Upon issuance of a license to collect or remove solid waste within the City required under the provisions of this article, the Department of Finance shall deliver to the licensee a registration license bearing the number of the particular license. The license shall be securely attached to the dash of the vehicle by the licensee in such a position and manner that it shall be at all times clearly visible upon visual inspection of the dash of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 25, 9-12-2000; Ord. No. G-1063, § 1, 4-28-2009; Ord. No. G-1177, § 11, 2-12-2013) 
Sec. 70-127. - Transfer. 
    No license to collect or remove solid waste within the City issued under the provisions of this article shall be assigned or transferred by the person holding the same as the licensee. Any licensee may, however, change the registration of the vehicle operated under such license upon the following conditions: 
(1)  The vehicle to be newly registered shall be inspected by the Police Department to determine compliance with this article. 
(2)  The registration of the vehicle previously operated under such license shall be surrendered. 
(3)  The sum established by ordinance as a fee for the transfer of registration of such vehicle shall be paid by the licensee to the Department of Finance. 
(4)  If the vehicle to be registered is of a greater gross weight rating than the vehicle originally registered, the licensee shall pay to the Department of Finance an additional sum to equal the fee as prescribed in Section 70-125. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 26, 9-12-2000; Ord. No. G-1177, § 12, 2-12-2013) 
Sec. 70-128. - Revocation; right of appeal. 
    If any licensee shall fail to comply with any provision of this article, the administrative authority may, upon 48 hours' written notice to such licensee, revoke and cancel such license to collect or remove solid waste within the City. Any licensee feeling aggrieved at such revocation may appeal, within five days, the action of the administrative authority to the Board of Commissioners. In no event will any portion of the license fee be refunded to the licensee upon revocation of such license. 
(Ord. No. G-858, § 31, 9-12-2000) 
Chapter 74 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance vacating any easement or park land saved from repeal, § 1-11(7); any ordinance levying or imposing any special assessment saved from repeal, § 1-11(9); any ordinance dedicating, establishing, naming, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, repairing or vacating any street saved from repeal, § 1-11(10); any ordinance establishing the grade or any street or sidewalk saved from repeal, § 1-11(11); aviation, ch. 14; buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; moving of buildings, § 18-501 et seq.; cemeteries, ch. 22; community development, ch. 26; library, ch. 38; solicitors and peddlers, § 42-171 et seq.; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 46; parks and recreation, ch. 58; planning, ch. 62; traffic and vehicles, ch. 78; one-way traffic upon certain streets, § 78-75; utilities, ch. 82. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 74-1. - Obstructions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct any street, alley, sidewalk, crossing, public ground or unoccupied ground in the City with any kind of vehicle, or with any box, lumber, or any other thing; or to place or cause to be placed in any street or alley, or upon any public or unoccupied ground, in this City, or in any mine, well, cistern tank, excavation or reservoir, or in any watercourse, ditch or gutter, any earth, dirt, carcass, filth, trash, rubbish, leaves, grass clippings, branches, limbs, refuse, or other unwholesome or injurious matter. 
(Code 1975, § 19-401; Ord. No. G-969, § 1, 4-12-2005) 
Sec. 74-2. - Encroaching on public grounds. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to encroach upon, into or over any sidewalk, street, alley, or public ground in the City with any house, building, structure, fixture or display of goods or other things, except awnings or signs. 
(Code 1975, § 19-402) 
Sec. 74-3. - Filling in gutters and ditches. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to fill in or obstruct any gutter or ditch in the City, designed for the purpose of draining any street, avenue or alley in such City, with any leaves, grass clippings, branches, limbs, dirt, ashes, rock, debris, concrete, cinders, shale, or any other substance, or to in any manner obstruct the natural flow of water down any such gutter or ditch; provided, however, that this chapter shall not prohibit a person from placing a tile or culvert in any such gutter or ditch, for the purpose of making a driveway or walk from any street or alley into private property, in such a manner as not to interfere with the natural flow of water down any such gutter or ditch, and in such a manner as not to create a hazard or dangerous defect in such street or alley. Any person desiring to place a tile or culvert in such gutter or ditch shall place the same under the direction of the City Engineer. 
(Code 1975, § 19-403; Ord. No. G-968, § 1, 4-12-2005) 
Sec. 74-4. - Poles, posts, monuments, signs or obstruction in streets or other public places. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to set or erect any pole, post, monument or sign, or in any manner place any obstruction, in or upon any street, alley, sidewalk or public ground without first having obtained a permit from the City Manager after a determination that such pole, post, monument, sign or other obstruction will not interfere with the view of or mislead or confuse traffic and is outside the visibility triangle as defined in the zoning ordinance; provided, however, that the restrictions in this Section shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Signs and supports placed by governmental authorities. 
(2)  Temporary signs used to announce a special event or activity when a special event permit has been issued. 
(3)  Poles, posts, monuments or obstructions erected, constructed or maintained by a public utility company franchised by the City when used as part of the company's distribution infrastructure. 
(Code 1975, § 19-404) 
Sec. 74-5. - Discharge of wastewater into streets or alleys. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person having the ownership, control or management of any building used for commercial purposes within the City, or any tenant or occupant of any such building in the City, to throw, place or in any way discharge or permit to be discharged into any street or alley in the City any wastewater which has been used for washing or cleaning purposes, for any refrigeration, cooling or air conditioning purposes or from any source whatsoever. 
(Code 1975, § 19-406) 
Cross reference- Sewer lines, § 82-241 et seq. 
Sec. 74-6. - Dragging trees, limbs, or other material over streets and alleys. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drag any tree, limb or branch, shrub, vine, pole, or other material on, over, or along any street, alley or public way in the City. 
(Code 1975, § 19-408) 
Sec. 74-7. - Removal of snow and ice from sidewalks; duty of owner. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner, occupant or agent of any lot or piece of ground adjoining or abutting upon any street, avenue or public way within the City where a sidewalk is located, either in front of or at the side or both of such lot or adjoining ground, to clean and remove therefrom all snow and ice within 24 hours after the same shall have fallen or accumulated on such sidewalk; provided, however, that if the fall or accumulation occurs in the nighttime, the same shall be removed not later than ten hours after sunrise. Where ice or compacted snow is of such a character as to make removal of the same from any sidewalk practically impossible, the sprinkling of sand, ashes or nonice-forming chemical may be applied within the time limited for the removal of snow and ice from sidewalks, and the same shall be deemed a compliance with the provisions of this Section. 
(Code 1975, § 12-401) 
Sec. 74-8. - Steps in sidewalk. 
    No steps in the sidewalk will be allowed except at the curb and then only by permission of the Governing Body, duly adopted by resolution. 
(Code 1975, § 19-106) 
Sec. 74-9. - Opening of cellar door through sidewalk. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make, provide, cause or allow any cellar door to be opened through the sidewalk which is not properly protected and guarded with grating or properly railed and guarded, subject to the approval of the City Engineer. 
(Code 1975, § 19-107) 
Sec. 74-10. - Neoclassic urns. 
(a)  Establishment of fund. The City is hereby authorized to accept contributions, donations, and gifts for the purchase, care, maintenance, repair and replacement of neoclassic urns in the downtown business district and place such funds in a separate account to be designated "The Neoclassic Urns Fund." 
(b)  Investment of funds. The Director of Finance shall be authorized to invest the monies in the neoclassic urns fund in the same manner that he is generally authorized to invest public monies; provided, however, that he shall not be authorized to expend the interest accruing from such investments without first receiving budget authority from the Governing Body and, thereafter, shall expend the funds only for the purchase, care, and maintenance, including repair and replacement, of the urns. 
(c)  Placement of flowers, plants, decorations or ornaments. The placement of flowers, plants, decorations or ornaments in or on the urns other than by the City, or without the express written authority of the Director of Parks and Recreation is prohibited. 
(d)  Additional written rules. The Director of Parks and Recreation is hereby authorized to promulgate additional written rules and regulations as deemed appropriate or necessary in connection with the care and maintenance of the neoclassic urns so long as the same do not conflict with the provisions of this Section. 
(Code 1975, §§ 22-201-22-204; Ord. No. G-1176, § 10, 2-12-2013) 
Sec. 74-11. - Devices prohibited on certain downtown sidewalks. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ride and use roller skates, roller blades, skateboards, bicycles, tricycles, unicycles, scooters, or other similar devices on all sidewalks on North Broadway Street between the intersection of First Street and the intersection of Eleventh Street. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ride and use roller skates, roller blades, skateboards, bicycles, tricycles, unicycles, scooters, or other similar devices upon any public and private property when a sign prohibiting such activity is conspicuously posted on the property. 
(3)  A violation of this section is a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not to exceed $100.00. 
(4)  Any roller skates, roller blades, skateboards, bicycle, tricycle, unicycle, scooters, or other similar device used in connection with said violation may be seized by a law enforcement officer at the time of the offense and released to the owner after ten days upon payment of a $20.00 impoundment fee to the City. 
(5)  This section shall not apply to law enforcement officers engaged in the performance of their official duties, or physically or mentally disabled persons riding and using self-propelled scooters and wheelchairs specifically designed for use by physically or mentally disabled persons. 
(Ord. No. G-1001, §§ 1-5, 12-12-2006) 
Secs. 74-12-74-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION 

Sec. 74-41. - Duty of City Engineer; approval of construction. 
    It shall be the duty of the City Engineer to oversee and supervise the construction of all sidewalks hereafter in the City, whether built by the property owners or the City, and he shall inspect all materials used in the construction of sidewalks under this article and for the purpose of making his inspection of any material used or about to be used in the construction of any sidewalk, he shall have the right to take a sufficient amount thereof for testing purposes, and retain the same in his possession, and he shall prevent the use of any materials which do not conform with the provisions of this article. All sidewalks shall be constructed under the orders and directions and the supervision of the City Engineer, and the same shall be subject to the approval of the City Engineer and the Board of Commissioners. 
(Code 1975, § 19-108) 
Sec. 74-42. - Manner and method of construction. 
    All public sidewalks hereafter constructed, repaired, or reconstructed within the City, shall be in accordance with standard plans and specifications prepared by the Department of Public Works, which plans and specifications shall be filed with the City Clerk and furnished to anyone who intends to construct, repair or reconstruct a sidewalk. 
(Code 1975, § 19-101) 
Sec. 74-43. - Establishment of grade. 
    No sidewalk shall be built on any of the public streets, avenues, alleys, or lands of the City by any person until the grade and the line next to the property line for the same shall have been established by the City Engineer, and when the alignment and grade for any walk shall be built in conformity thereto. It shall be the duty of the City Engineer, when requested by any property owner, his agent or the City, to furnish the alignment and grade stakes for any sidewalk as provided in this article. 
(Code 1975, § 19-103) 
Sec. 74-44. - Width and location of sidewalk. 
    The width and location of public sidewalks shall be determined by the City Engineer but in no case shall such sidewalk be less than four feet unless the Governing Body declares, by resolution, the width of a sidewalk to be located at a specified place. 
(Code 1975, § 19-104) 
Sec. 74-45. - Slope of sidewalk or parking; handicap ramp exception. 
    Where the sidewalk extends from the property line to the curb, the sidewalk shall have a transversal slope of one-fifth inch per foot and where the sidewalk does not extend from the property line to the curb, the sidewalk shall have a transversal slope of one-fourth inch per foot. The parking or space between the sidewalk and the curb shall have a slope toward the curb of not less than one-fourth inch per foot and not more than one inch per foot; provided, however, that handicap accessibility ramps constructed pursuant to design standards approved by the Director of Public Works as well as the following specified handicap accessibility ramps shall be exempt from the requirements of this Section: 
(1)  At Broadway where it is intersected by Hudson Street, Lindburg Street, Cleveland Street, Williams Street, Jefferson Street and Quincy Street and where Broadway is intersected by Twentieth, Twenty-Second and Twenty-Third Streets as well as Third Street through Tenth Street. 
(2)  At Fourth Street where it intersects Walnut Street, North Water Street, Village Road, Victorian Drive, and Free King Highway. 
(3)  At Joplin Street where it intersects with Cleveland, Ford, and Lindburg Avenues. 
(4)  At Pine Street where it intersects with First through Tenth Streets. 
(5)  At Rouse Avenue where it intersects with Fourth through Sixteenth Streets. 
(6)  At Locust Street where it intersects with East Lindburg Street and Third Street through Tenth Street. 
(7)  At Ford Avenue where it intersects Homer Street and South Elm Street. 
(8)  At Lindburg Street where it is intersected by South Elm Street. 
(Code 1975, § 19-105) 
Sec. 74-46. - Duty to repair sidewalks; how repairs made. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner or the occupant of real property adjoining a public sidewalk to keep the same in a good and proper state of repair. The repair shall be made of material having quality equal to that required for new construction and shall be so laid as to correspond with the dimensions and grade of the rest of the sidewalk in front of the lot or parcel of land. Provided however, the City shall be responsible for the repair of damage to the public sidewalk caused by the roots of trees planted in the public sidewalk by the City between and including the 200 block of Broadway Street and the 1200 block of Broadway Street. 
(Code 1975, § 19-110; Ord. No. G-1040, § 1, 5-13-2008) 
Sec. 74-47. - Cost of repairs made by City. 
    Subject to the provisions of Section 74-46, if the owners or occupants of land adjoining public sidewalks shall refuse, neglect or fail to repair the sidewalks, it shall be the duty of the City Engineer, after giving five days' written notice to each owner or his agent, if known, of the necessity of repair, and without such notice if the lot or parcel of land be unoccupied, to make repairs at any time, keeping an accurate account of the cost thereof and reporting the same to the Governing Body of the City, which shall levy a special assessment against the lot or parcel of land abutting on the sidewalk so repaired for the costs of such repairs, which shall be collected as other special assessments according to law. 
(Code 1975, § 19-111; Ord. No. G-1040, §; 2, 5-13-2008) 
Secs. 74-48-74-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DRIVEWAYS 

Sec. 74-81. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this Section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commercial/industrial driveway entrance means all areaways affording access to private property upon which is conducted commercial or industrial business, including the servicing, storing or parking of motor vehicles; and areaways affording access to public property upon which a public function or convenience is conducted. 
    Curb return means the portion of the curb nearest to a driveway entrance which includes the radius of curvature, or the ramp-type flare approach which connects the driveway entrance to the street curb. 
    Driveway means a private roadway providing access for vehicles to a parking space, garage, dwelling or other structure. 
    Driveway entrance means an area, construction or facility between the roadway of the public street and private property intended to provide access for vehicles from the roadway of a public street to private property. 
    Private driveway entrance means every driveway entrance not constituting a commercial or industrial driveway entrance shall be classified as a private driveway entrance. 
(Code 1975, § 19-201) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 74-82. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, alter or reconstruct a driveway entrance in the City, without first obtaining a permit. 
(Code 1975, § 19-202) 
Sec. 74-83. - Crossing, curbing or breaking curbs; unlawful acts. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person willfully to drive, or cause or permit to be driven, any vehicle or machinery over or across any curb or sidewalk in any street or avenue of the City or to damage, break or cut any curb, gutter or sidewalk, except as may be authorized under a permit from the Department of Public Works issued in accordance with the ordinances of the City relating to street parkings, curbs and gutters, and as provided for in this article for the construction of driveway entrances. 
(Code 1975, § 19-203) 
Sec. 74-84. - Driveway entrances; unlawful to extend. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, alter or extend, or permit or cause to be constructed, altered or extended any driveway entrance which can be used only as a parking space between the roadway and adjacent property line, except in connection with a permit authorized by this article upon the approval of the Governing Body. 
(Code 1975, § 19-204) 
Sec. 74-85. - Construction of driveway entrances; regulations. 
    The construction, alteration or reconstruction of driveway entrances, including the cutting and removal of curbs and gutters, shall be authorized upon the issuance of a permit by the Department of Public Works after the receipt of an application in accordance with the following requirements: 
(1)  No driveway entrance shall be constructed which will interfere with public facilities, including street lighting poles, traffic signals standards, signs, catchbasins, hydrants, water meters, crosswalks, loading zones, utility poles, fire alarm supports, underground pipes or ducts or other necessary street structures. 
(2)  No driveway entrance for a private driveway shall be less than eight feet nor exceed 24 feet in width; and for commercial/industrial driveway, more than 40 feet in width. 
(3)  The width at the roadway for a private driveway shall not exceed 36 feet, nor shall the radii or flare be less than four feet or more than six feet. The width for a commercial/industrial driveway shall not exceed 60 feet, measured at the roadway, nor shall the radii or flare be less than six feet or more than ten feet. 
(4)  Driveway entrances shall be installed at a right angle to the curbline or roadway. 
(5)  No driveway entrance shall be constructed in a manner to change or interfere with the gutter flow line or sidewalk grade where such driveway entrance crosses any such gutter or sidewalk, except upon approval of the Department of Public Works. 
(6)  The sidewalk and curb shall, insofar as possible, be cut, and removed at the nearest joint and upon replacement and reconstruction, suitable joints shall be provided in all such work in accordance with the specifications of the Department of Public Works with all joints to be filled by a bituminous fiber or compound. 
(7)  All drainage tile used driveway entrances shall be class III reinforced concrete for pipe as sized by the Department of Public Works. 
(8)  The cost of construction of all driveway entrances and necessary appurtenances thereto shall be borne by the permittee. 
(9)  All driveway entrances shall be constructed of concrete with a design strength of 3,500 psi. 
(10)  No driveway entrance shall be installed which will interfere with the free and safe movement of traffic. 
(11)  No driveway entrance will have a slope less than one-half inch per foot. 
(Code 1975, § 19-205) 
Sec. 74-86. - Variance from strict application. 
    The Director of Public Works is hereby authorized to grant, in writing, as part of any permit issued by him, variances from the strict application of the provisions of this article, upon determining that the following conditions are present: 
(1)  Exception or variance desired arises from peculiar physical conditions not ordinarily existing in similar districts in the City or is due to the nature of business and operations on the abutting property. 
(2)  Exception or variance desired is not against the public interest, safety, convenience and general welfare. 
(3)  The granting of the permit for the exception or variance will not adversely affect the right of adjacent property owners or tenants. 
(4)  The strict application of the provisions of this article will work unnecessary hardship on the property owner or tenant. 
(Code 1975, § 19-206) 
Sec. 74-87. - Standard plans and specifications. 
    The Department of Public Works shall prepare standard plans and specifications for the construction of driveway entrances, sidewalk crossings and curbs, and shall furnish them to any permittee upon application. It shall be the duty of the Department of Public Works to enforce the provisions of this article and to supervise all work authorized by a permit. 
(Code 1975, § 19-207) 
Sec. 74-88. - Distance between driveway entrance and intersection. 
    No driveway entrance hereafter located, constructed or altered shall be located closer than 25 feet to an intersection measuring from the nearest end of the curb cut to the intersection point of the extended curbline or roadway. 
(Code 1975, § 19-208) 
Sec. 74-89. - Location with reference to lot lines. 
    No driveway entrance or curb cut shall hereafter be made, constructed, located or altered so as to be located outside the extended lot lines of the private property to which the driveway entrance affords access. 
(Code 1975, § 19-209) 
Sec. 74-90. - Multiple commercial/industrial entrances. 
    There shall be no more than two commercial/industrial entrances permitted on each street fronting the property. A minimum distance of 80 feet shall be maintained between the centerlines of commercial/industrial driveway entrances for any one business or purpose. 
(Code 1975, § 19-210) 
Sec. 74-91. - Restoration or construction of curb when driveway entrance is no longer necessary. 
    If a driveway entrance is used only for a parking space or such driveway ceases to be used for access to private property, it shall be the duty of the owner or occupant of such property to eliminate such unused or unnecessary driveway entrance and to construct and restore the curb, gutter and sidewalk in accordance with the specifications on file in the Department of Public Works. 
(Code 1975, § 19-211) 
Sec. 74-92. - Joint driveway entrance. 
    A joint driveway entrance shall be allowed only when an easement of record is on file with the county register of deeds, describing the joint right of access. 
(Code 1975, § 19-212) 
Secs. 74-93-74-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 74-121. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this Section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Person means any person, partnership, company, association, corporation or any other person or combination of persons, either natural or artificial, by whatever name he or they may be called. 
(Code 1975, § 19-301) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 74-122. - To be under supervision of City Engineer. 
    All excavations, refills, resurfacing, replacements, or protective measures covered by this article shall be subject to the supervision and approval of the City Engineer. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail, neglect or refuse to obey the orders or directions of the City Engineer in filling any excavation, including the replacing of any pavement or sidewalk taken up or disturbed in making such excavation, and shall be unlawful for any person to fail, neglect or refuse for 24 hours after receiving notice from the City Engineer that the place where an excavation had been made was out of repair by reason of such excavation having been made, and filled, to repair such place under the order of the City Engineer.
